This is a 62 year old woman with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presents with anterior STEMI. She saw her PCP   with ten days of back pain between her scapula and it was felt she had a radiculopathy. She then presented to  ED on  for worsening back pain, shoulder and neck pain associated with vomiting. EKG performed at that time showed ST elevations in leads I, avL, V2-V5. She was not cathed at that time as symptoms had been present for 10 days and were improving. CPK 1670, MB 99.2, RI 8.1, Trop 3.24. She was cathed at the outside hospital on day of admission to  and found to have subtotally occluded LAD. She was then transferred here for PCI. Sheath in RFA, pulses dopplerable. She was given 600mg of plavix and aspirin 325mg on morning of admission along with 20mg lasix for LVEDP of 35 mmHG. Echo revealed an LVEF of %. Upon transfer to , she underwent cardiac catheterization with PCI of LAD. She was started on integrillin. Upon transfer to the CCU, she continued to endorse back pain however she feels it considerably improved. . Prior to this event, she has never had any overt anginal symptoms. Her exercise tolerance is good, with no shortness of breath or anginal equivalents with exercise. She used to swim frequently however in the past several months, following her husband's death in , she has stopped exercising. Cardiac risk factors include hypertension and hyperlipidemia, and she has been on atenolol and simvastatin for these issues respectively. She has never had any prior MIs, known coronary disease, stress tests, or cardiac catheterization. . Review of systems is negative for chest pressure/pain, shortness of breath, nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain, headache, blurry vision, dysuria, fevers, chills.

72 y/o male with COPD, CAD s/p angioplasty in , afib and small cell lung CA who started   with carboplatin/VP-16 in . He initially presented to SMMC on  with hypotension after accidental overdose on diltiazem. There, a CXR showed R lung white out and was transferred to  for bronch given concern for mass compression of the bronchus. Chest CT at  showed large centrally obstructing mass with right apical pneumothorax, right middle and lower lobe opacity, pigtail was placed. Patient was then bronched on  with purulent drainage, stent was placed and started on Vanco/Zosyn for presumed post-obstructive pneumonia. Patient continued to be intubated after the bronch and developed hypotension requiring pressors. Patient also noted to be neutropenic thought likely   and sepsis and patient with afib with RVR on a dilt gtt. Patient self-extubated on  and was subsequently re-intubated for hypoxia and respiratory distress. A repeat bronch was performed to open collapse. He was also started on radiation chemotherapy to shrink the tumor in his chest.

Mr.  is a 24 y/o M who was transferred to  from  Hospital on  after he accidently shot himself in the right mandible while playing with a gun. An emergency tracheostomy was performed, and a 4 vessel angiography was performed, which revealed no major injury to his vertebral arteries. A CT sinus/mandible/maxilla revealed a comminuted fracture at the ramus of the right mandible, with a comminuted minimally displaced C1 fracture. A large bullet fragment was found to rest medial to the ramus of the left mandible. He was placed in a C-spine collar, to be in place for 6 weeks, and was admitted to the Trauma Surgery service for further evaluation and care.

80yoM with h/o AFib, CHF, HTN, Hypercholesterolemia transferred from Caritas  for evaluation of flail posterior mitral valve repair. Pt was admitted to  in  for Legionella pneumonia when he had multilobar infiltrates, received 2-3wk course of oral ABx and resolution of PNA. He was doing well, then had a motor vehicle accident  due to syncopal episode at which point per pt he began to have off and on SOB and was told to have a stress test and echocardiogram, the results of which are below, but basically the stress test was negative and the TTE was most significant for flail posterior mitral leaflet with either subchordal rupture or vegetation, 4+ MR, 3+ TR, concentric LVH, and evidence of volume overload. Pt was then admitted to Caritas  for further workup of what appears to be initially most concerning for the vegetation, which included TEE. TEE ruled out vegetation and showed a flail posterior mitral leaflet with subchordal rupture with severe 4+ MR.  there were mostly significant for WBC count 10.3, BUN/Cr 28/1.3-1.4. BCx's negative x3. The pt is transferred to  for workup of mitral valve repair. ROS significant for increased fatigue, SOB, DOE, occasional PND/orthopnea, occasional palpitations. He also endorses two syncopal episodes in the past several months. He mentions a 30lb wt loss when he was recently diuresed with Lasix, he denies that he's ever had heart failure or swelling before. He feels that his condition has been deteriorating since his episode of PNA. He denies f/c/ns, no CP, no HEENT problems, no n/v/d/c/abdominal pain, no dysuria, no skin changes, no joint changes.
History of rollover motor vehicle accident with trauma to neck. History of tingling in ulnar nerve distribution bilaterally. past history of neck pain.

History of Present Illness: Mr.  is a 64M with a history of active prostate cancer s/p completion of radiation tx yesterday, who presented to  with dyspnea on exertion.   documentation, he was walking upstairs to do laundry, and when he came back down he had persistent shortness of breath. He has had some intermittent DOE for the last several months, but is usually able to catch his breath with rest whereas today he felt persistently SOB. According to his wife, he was told that his grandson (to whom he is very attached) was in a MVA, and after that he became very anxious and SOB. She thinks anxiety may play a large role in his SOB.

The patient woke the morning of admission and had one episode of vomiting with breakfast and then went back to sleep. His uncle got him up for lunch where he again vomited and again wanted to return to sleep. As the patient was recently discharge from  Hitchcock s/p abscess removal and hydrocephalus, the patient's uncle and aunt were concerned and brought him into a local ED at . At  he got a head CT w/wo contrast that showed a possible rind enhancing lesion although as they didn't have his prior imaging they could not tell if this was surgical change vs residual/recurrent abscess, and he was sent to  for further evaluation. Per the patient and the family he has only had some increased sleepiness, and has not had the headaches, hallucinations and unresponsiveness he had when he was initially diagnosed with his brain lesions. Of note the patient had a motor vehicle accident around mid . He had likely passed out behind the wheel. He was taken to  for evaluation when fluid filled cysts were noted on his imaging. Given his immuncompromised history these cysts were removed from the ventricular wall and foramen of , and an EVD was placed. The cultures returned C.albicans, and he was placed on a month of amphotericin and 5-flucytosine. The patient EVD was removed and an endoscopic 3rd ventriculostomy was performed. The patient was d/c last week on fluconazole.

Mr.  is a 50 year old man in good health until a motorcycle accident on  who presented from rehab with tachycardia and concern for a pulmonary embolism. Mr.  crashed a motorcycle on  at which point he sustained multiple orthopedic injuries including T10/11 compression fracture with small epidural hematoma, C7 non-displaced pedicle fracture, multiple spinous process and transverse process fractures, and left radial/ulnar open fractures. He underwent multiple orthopedic procedures at  and was discharged to rehab on . Since then he had been doing well and progressing with physical therapy. Two days prior to presentation, however, he was noted to be tachycardic and his O2 sat dropped to the 80's once during PT. Due to these issues he was sent to an outside hospital where he had a CT that raise concern for PE though he continued to deny any chest pain or dyspnea. He had a chest radiograph that was concerning for pneumonia and went on to receive a dose of levofloxacin at the outside hospital. He denied cough, fevers, chills, or hypoxia.

78 yo F with PMH of COPD on 2L home O2, CAD with stent on ASA/ transferred from  Hospital after MVA yestserday with a question of syncopal episode prior to driving off the road. She was admitted to the trauma service where she was evaluated by Neurosurgery for ? SAH and L lateral ventricular bleed per report. . Neurosurgery consult though the reported SAH might have been an overcall and thought it was a trivial SAH. They recommended starting Dilantin (x7d), get CTA to assess for aneurysm, perform syncope workup, q4 Neuro checks, goal SBP <160. She was started on Dilantin, Aspirin/plavix were held. . CT chest was concerning for ground-glass appearance, consistent with pulmonary contusions and hemorrhage. Patient subsequently developed a leukocytosis of 23.6, with positive UA and pending urine culture. Tmax 101.5 at 10 pm on . Started on ceftriaxone for PNA without atypical coverage. Received 10 mg IV lasix this AM for ? volume overload. .

63M with PVD, EtOH and cocaine abuse, admitted to  Hospital on  with septic shock and E.coli bacteremia, now transferred to  for further workup and potential ERCP. . He presented on  with lethargy, disorientation, and fever to 105 with abdominal pain after his roommate called EMS. Blood cultures grew E.coli bacteremia and he developed septic shock and was admitted to the ICU. He was intubated and required both vasopressin and norepinephrine. Started on meropenem (and later changed to irtapenem). He had perc CCY tube placed on . Pressors were weaned off. He also had NSTEMI in setting of his sepsis with peak troponin 37.88 on . Echo showed EF 25-30% with severe global LV HK. There was also concern for worsening RLE ischemia on pressors vs. true graft thrombosis. On  he went to the OR for RLE AKA and cholecystectomy. Procedure notable for somewhat difficult to remove gallbladder with some resultant bleeding in gallbladder fossa. No intraop cholangiogram per procedure notes. He was extubated on . Post op noted to have increasing amylase (to 551) and lipase (to 288). Also developed fever to 100.8. Could not get MRCP due to shrapnel in eye (though wife does not know anything about this), so being transferred to  for ERCP to evaluate these new changes. . Speaking with patient's wife, she notes a change in mental status since extubation. Extubated on  and she reports that he recognized her and other family members that night. However, the following day and yesterday he has been confused about where he is and who friends and family were. Also slurring speech worse (has some slur at baseline). No noted weakness in UEs/LEs. Has baseline facial asymmetry since MVA. . In the , patient appears comfortable. Delerious and disoriented but calm. Denies pain of any type. ROS as below.

26 yo man who was found down, with a GCS of 3, in a pool of blood/vomit, on a highway. Proposed mechanisms of injury include falling off overpass vs. pedestrian struck.He was taken to an outside hospital and intubated using etomidate and succinylcholine. The tube was found to be slightly high and the patient had a white out of the leftchest. He was then transferred to  for further evaluation.

Ms  is a 72 year-old female with pmh of hypertension, HL, depression, and GERD who was admitted to the MICU on  due to hypotension after she developed chest pressure in the ED. She describes being under a lot of stress as she came to the ED with husband who was in a traumatic traffic accident after having a stroke. She describes this her chest pressure as a band across the chest below her left breast and into her back. Upon further history she endorses URI symptoms and similar chest pressure dating back 7-14 days. She says that pressure is unrelated to activity, but is accompanied by some shortness of breath. She denies relationship to food. She also endorses having occassional dark stool 1x/week. She had an episode of non-bloody emesis in the ER. Her EKGs in the ED did not show any ischemic changes and her CK was normal, however her trop was elevated to 0.45. She was hypotensive with SBPs in the 70's to 80's. She was given 4 L IVF and started on zosyn, flagyl, and clindamycin. A central line was placed and she was also started on neo. A CT torso and abdominal US showed gallbladder wall edema and pericholecystic fluid. Surgery was consulted and they did not feel it was acute cholecystitis. Patient was started on Zosyn, Flagyl, Clindamycin. This morning because of the persistently elevated troponin and TWI in V4-V6, patient was sent to cath lab. Catheterization demonstrated normal LMCA, LAD, LCX, and RCA coronary arteries as well as moderate elevation of R/L heart filling pressures. Echo demonstrated apical hypokinesis with severe MR   leaflet. CO 3.55, CI 2.12. Patient was transferred to CCU without intervention. Patient endorses continued chest pressure. . On review of systems, she denies any prior history of stroke, TIA, deep venous thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, bleeding at the time of surgery, abdominal pain. She denies recent fevers. Last hospitalization 10 years ago. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, syncope or presyncope.

This is an 84 yo male with DM, CRI, dementia, CVA, seizure disorder, and recent MVA who was originally transferred from an OSH for a right perinephric hematoma which he suffered from a twisting motion while getting out of bed. He was originally admitted to trauma surgery where he had an embolization of one of the branches of the right renal artery done by IR. His hematocrit remained stable. . His course was complicated by a worsening pleural effusion thought to be  lymphatic tracking originating from the perinephric space. A therapeutic tap of 1500mL of serosanguinous fluid was done because he desaturated to 89% on RA. Other complications include elevated troponins to 0.22 with normal CK and CKMB, and new TWI in V1-V3. No report of chest pain. . Then he was admitted to the MICU for mental status change. He remained hemodynamically stable and is now transferred to the regular floors for further management.

62 yo M c HTN, HL initially presented to  Hospital on  with a fever and cough 2-3 months after a trip to  . The patient has no symptoms in his usual state of health other than occasional headaches. He spent most of his vacation at a resort on the coast and did some diving in the ocean, but did not go into the rainforest or have exposure to exotic animals. . He states that his initial symptoms occurred 2-3 weeks ago, when he developed "chest heaviness", fevers to 101, and a cough productive of yellow sputum. When he initially presented, CXR was unremarkable and patient was d/ced on Z-pak. Patient re-presented on  with persistent fever, cough and was noted to have a mild transaminitis (AST ~ 50). He also had developed some nausea and vomiting. His simvastatin was discontinued. At that time, abdominal ultrasound showed mild hepatomegaly without biliary dilation or gallstones and hepatitis panel was reportedly normal. CT sinus showed mild mucosal thickening; CT head was normal. He was again discharged home but again re-presented on  with fever and headache. At this time, an LP (glucose 62, protein 23, WBC 4, culture negative, Lyme PCR negative), CT chest/abd, repeat CXR, Lyme serology, CMV IgG, malaria smear, and serologic test for babesia was performed. All of these tests were normal but the patient was discharged on empiric doxycycline pending final results. . He was re-admitted on  with fever, shaking chills, and recurrent cough productive of yellow sputum with mild streaking of blood. In the OSH ED, a D-dimer was positive, and the patient was sent for CTA chest. Both this and a CXR showed evidence of R lung airspace disease (RUL/RML/RLL) and small effusions, R > L. He was started on CTX and continued on doxycycline. He underwent a bronchoscopy and BAL that was limited by intraprocedural hypoxemia. Lavage was sent for bacterial, fungal, AFB/TB cultures. At this time, the patient requested a transfer to . At the time of discharge, as it was felt the patient may have a nosocomial infection, his CTX was switched to Zosyn. . The patient states that his fevers are episodic, lasting hours at a time, and are associated with shaking chills and sweats, especially when they are high (peaking at 104). The episodes occur every few days and occur both at day and night. . At the time of transfer, pending tests included BAL results, ANCA and anti-GBM antibodies. . The patient denies rash, weight loss, diarrhea, constipation, arthralgias. Endorses genralized weakness. ROS otherwise noncontributory.

78 year old female with history of severe aortic stenosis who woke up this morning, felt ill, got out of bed and felt nauseated. She walked several steps, fell forward and broke her fall with her arms. She did not lose consciousness. She did not hit her head. She crawled to the phone an called an ambulance and was taken to the  ED, where she was noted to have chest pain. In addition, she was vomitting, Cold (96 rectally), diaphoretic and hypotensive to 74/56. Per her sister, the patient has been non-compliant with her medications due to high cost. She accidentally took double her dose of HCTZ for several weeks. In the  ED, the patient was given intravenous fluids, zofran, morphine 1mg, ASA 325mg, and was started on a heparin drip with a Bolus of 5750U at 1320 and a drp at 1300U/hr. Her chest pain resolved after 1mg of morphine. She had a troponin of 0.22, and ST depressions in the lateral leads. She was transferred to  for cardiac catheterization.

34 yo male s/p unrestrained MVA 1 wek ago and he reports a question of a thoracic fracture at that time. He reports pain now in his groin, abdomen, LE, L chest, and back of the neck on both sides. 4 days ago he developed worsening pain and found it extremely painful to get up due to LE muscle soreness. He reports 5 days ago he began to have watery diarrhea 3-4x a day with only 2 episodes on the day of admission. He drank large amounts of water but had extreme thirst. He also notes feeling dizzy. He started having fever up to 102.7 2 days ago and to 103 the morning of admission. He stopped making urine on Saturday. For his pain he's been taking aspirin 2 tabs BIS, Percocet 5/day, he finished 4 pills of tylenol with codeine, and he's been taking Ibuprofen 800mg 2 pills QID. He denies any use of cocaine. . He presented to the  with vitals of T 98.1 BP 104/53 P123 RR20 96% on NRM. He was found to have PNA, transaminitis ARF, hyponatremia, gap of 19 with bicarb 19, WBC of 4.6, HCT 37.9, and plts of 67. In the ED CT scan chest/abd/pelvis notable for multifocal PNA and LAD. At the OSH he got ancef 1gram, 2L IVF, morphine 4mg, and dilaudid 1mg. In the ambulance he received 2L IVF, zofran 4mg IVx1, 50mg of fentanyl, and a duoneb. He got 2 additional liters of IVF on route to BBI . On arrival to the ED at  vitals were T98.9 BP108/64 HR 133 RR24 86% on NRB (touble getting o2 sat likely never this low). HR ranged 117-129 SBP 99-128/54-82 RRR 19-33. Labs additionally notable for lactate of 2.2. Lung exam was notable for Rhonchi. Pt tachypnic but speaking in full sentences. He made 1600cc of urine in ED which was after 5L of IVF counting all the fluid since arrival to . He received Vancomycin 1gram IV x1, levoquin 750mg IV once, and flagyl was ordered but not given prior to transfer. He also received NS x1 L, calcium gluconate 1gm x1, mg sulfate 2grams x1, and dilaudid 1mg IV x1. Urine tox, urine lytes, and serum tox were pending at the time of transfer. Vitals prior to transfer were T98.4 HR117 BP 99/46 (SBP as low as 95 per ED resident) RR33 94% on 5L NC.

74y F with HTN, HL, DM p/w a CC of ejected from her dinghy while trying to park it on her neighbors'  and hit her face over the right maxilla. This 49 year old truck driver experienced chest pressure while sitting in his truck. He denies chest pain with exertion. A stress test in  was positive and stopped due to fatigue. HPI: 49yo M, with no significant PMH, who presented with minor  right frontal headache since Wedensday, and slightly worse today. simvastatin coumadin B 12 FeSo4 MVI prilosec bisacodyl mirtazepine senna
The patient is a 33-year-old gentleman with a history of a motor vehicle accident complicated by a seizure disorder who presents with a left hip fracture after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure.

The patient is an 85 year old female who was found down unresponsive by her family. She was brought to the Emergency Room at an outside hospital. This is a 47-year-old man with a past medical history significant for multiple myocardial infarctions in the past, hypertension, obesity, insulin dependent-diabetes mellitus, gastroesophageal reflux disease, history of cerebrovascular accident, high cholesterol, chronic renal insufficiency with a baseline creatinine of 1.2-1.5, bilateral foot peripheral neuropathy, trigeminal neuralgia, and past surgical history significant for hernia and appendectomy in  as well as bilateral laser surgery of the eyes for his retinopathy.

44 y/o man with HIV (last cd4 over 440 on ; VL was 2.4 K at this time and had been previously undetectable for years), MRSA skin infection  with necrotic component requiring extensive OR debridement, mult MVC who presents to the ED today complaining of 1 day of generalized malaise, lightheadedness, and lt. flank pain. The patient is a 55 year old male with a history of coronary artery disease with a myocardial infarction at age 20, also history of diabetes mellitus, and cerebrovascular accident, who was transferred emergently to  catheterization laboratory from outside hospital. The patient was diaphoretic the p.m. of admission, reportedly took his medicines and went to bed. He was then found unresponsive in bed by his family and EMS was called. He had a prolonged code in the field by EMS and was given initially 2 mg of Atropine and 6 mg of Epinephrine and was transferred to the outside hospital Emergency Department. At the outside hospital Emergency Department, he was found to be in ventricular fibrillation and given Epinephrine and followed by defibrillation times three, followed by Lidocaine and followed by one more defibrillation attempt, which resulted in sinus tachycardia with a rate of 140 and systolic blood pressure of 110/50, and fingerstick of 36. He then became hypotensive at 53/35 and developed PEA and was given Epinephrine times two. He was then started on Levophed and Dopamine and transferred to .

62 y/o female with known MS for many years who recently has had an increase in dyspnea on exertion, shortness of breath, and fatigue. HPI: 20 M with history of paraplegia s/p MVA , transferred from OSH on  for pna, ARDS, bacteremia, rapid-antigen +influenza B. Being transferred from  to floor. . The patient is an 82-year-old female with a past medical history significant for aortic stenosis (status post aortic valve replacement), hypertension, and hypercholesterolemia who was recently discharged from  on  following evaluation and treatment for a gait instability secondary to embolic cerebrovascular accident in the setting of a ruptured mitral valve chordae tendinae (and valvular vegetations on transesophageal echocardiogram per Discharge Summary) who presents from  Rehabilitation with hypotension.

This is a 75 year-old man with a past medical history of cerebrovascular accident with residual right hemiparesis in  as well as diabetes type 2, coronary artery disease, status post catheterization in  with three vessel disease as well as cataracts, hyperlipidemia and bipolar disorder who is admitted to  on  after he was found down in his home. He was diagnosed with a left basal ganglia intracranial hemorrhage likely arising from the caudate with large intraventricular extension on the left. He had subsequent hydrocephalus as well as an acute myocardial infarction with troponins going greater then 50 as well as rhabdomyolysis with a CK in the 10,000s. He was admitted to the Neurological Intensive Care Unit for closer blood pressure and neurologic monitoring. It was felt early on as his decreased level of consciousness was profound he would need neurosurgical intervention with a right ventricular catheter. This was placed on  the day after admission. After insertion the catheter continued to have 200 to 300 cc output a day of blood tinged fluid and his mental status seemed to improve. On admission he had low grade fevers 100 to 101 range with an increased white blood cell count of 90.5. Initial workup showed pneumonia with right upper lobe infiltrate and also a question of left lower lobe infiltrate. He was given Ancef initially for his drain on the first day, however, it was then changed to Levaquin as well as Flagyl in light of his cultures came back. He required intubation on . He was later started on Vancomycin with cultures coming back as heavy growth MRSA.

The patient is a 20 year old previously healthy man transferred from Bermuda after sustaining a closed head injury secondary to motorcycle crash . He was unresponsive at that accident site and presented to the Emergency Department with   Coma Score of 3. He had a right frontal hemorrhagic contusion with numerous skull and facial fractures and air noted within the skull vault. EEG was done and the patient was found to have no activity to noxious stimuli. A liver laceration was noted with blood in the pelvis and the patient underwent exploratory laparotomy. There were no abnormalities in the spleen or bowel and liver bleeding was stopped after hemostasis with packing. No repair to the liver was needed. A right tibial fracture repair was also performed with two cancellous screws placed.

This 39 year old man w/ PMH of quadraplegia, Sz and MDS presents with altered mental status. He was seen in the ED 9 days ago after a fall from his wheelchair, striking his face. Over the past 3 days he has become increasingly confused,being disorientation to place and time. Disorientation originally started with difficulty with coordination, then progressed to confusion (unable to dress self) and then lost verbal abilities. He has also had growing anxiety and repetitive questioning. He underwent a CT of his head at  that was reportedly negative. U/A was borderline positive and per old records altered mental status is his classic presentation for UTI, but he has never been confused to the point of being non-verbal as he currently is. C4 paralysis from MVA 21 years ago. At baseline is self sufficient. drives, shops, has MBA. Also had baclofen pump refilled around 2 weeks ago. . In the ED Temp 100.0 F, BP 102/45, HR 89, R , O2-sat 95 % RA he was only answering simple questions yes/no and was noted to have repetitive lip smacking movments. Serum tox was negative, U/A borderline positive and cardiac enzymes were positive. His EKG had some mild STD in lateral leads and cardiology was consulted and did not feel that this was acute. He was given ceftriaxone, vancomycin, acyclovir and flagyl after blood and urine cultures were taken. . On floor, patient was able to follow simple commands and speaking one word at a time. He denied any pain.

This is a 54 year old male transferred from an OSH status-post a motorcycle crash earlier in the evening. He was found to have a grade 4 splenic laceration on OSH CT and was transferred to  for emergent exploratory laparotomy on . All other imaging from the OSH was reportedly negative.

A 72-year-old nondiabetic white male status post cerebrovascular accident with left hemiparesis, occluded right internal carotid artery, status post left carotid endarterectomy, with hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, chronic renal insufficiency, pyelonephritis, was found to have a pulsatile abdominal mass on routine physical exam in early  of this year.

45 yo female with strong family h/o of CAD, no known CAD presents to OSH 1 hour after experiencing intermittent but persistent sub-sternal chest pain with radiation to elbows and associated SOB. Hemodynamically stable at OSH but EKG showing ST elevations in inferior leads and ST depressions in lead 1, aVL, and v1-V3 - consistent with inferiorposterior STEMI. Given ASA, Beta Blocker, IV Heparin, and TNK, and transferred to  for catherization. Cath showed spontaneous dissection of the Left Circumflex extending from the proximal portion of the Left Circumflex to distal OM branches. The Left Main CA, and Right CA had no angiographically apparent disease. LAD had 10% ostial lesion (right dominant system). Underwent PCIx3 with driver stents. Echo showed 40-45% ejection fraction with evidence of inferior hypokinesis. Cardiac enzymes peaked at a CPK of 1005 and Troponin of 3.65 before starting to trend down.

The patient is a 26 year old woman with a history of seizures since age 21 following head trauma in a motor vehicle accident now presenting with a seizure earlier today. The patient is unable to give a coherent and reliable history so most details are taken from her home care taker , who I spoke to on the phone. She tells me that the patient was sleeping on the sofa as she walked by the room. She woke her up and asked her if everything was okay. She told her "my mouth hurts". The patient then tried to get off the sofa, fell to her knees and began an episode of whole body shaking that lasted about a minute or so. During the seizure, dropped her torso to the floor and hit her face on the ground. Her face was bleeding. After the seizure she was confused and somewhat lethargic.  then activated EMS and the patient was brought to  for further management.

1. This gentleman has a long history of cardiac disease with a diagnosis of tetralogy of Fallot. 2. In  he had a classic right Blalock-Taussig shunt. 3. In  he had a complete repair. 4. Ms.  is an 82 year old female with a history of dementia, Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, htn, GERD who presents with melena and coffee ground emesis beginning this am. However, she has 24 hr care at home and her home health aid notes that she has been in her usual state of health until this am with the exception of a cough which began recently. Upon arrival to the ICU, patient is without complaint except for some pain in her back and L foot. She notes both are chronic. She describes an accident where she injured her L foot but cannot recall specifics. She denies all other ROS including fevers, chills, cough, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, chest pain, shortness of breath. She cannot recall events which brought her to the ICU.

Considering his quality of life (on hemodialysis, little self-awareness, poor orientation, frequent agitation), the decision was made to discontinue  and focus on improving quality of life in transition to hospice.

This 74 year old white female has been complaining of left parasternal pain, blurred vision, tinnitus, lightheadedness and dyspnea on exertion for a few weeks. She underwent cardiac catheterization on , at , which revealed an ejection fraction of 70 percent, an 85 percent left anterior descending coronary artery lesion, a 60 percent right coronary artery lesion and aortic valve area of 0.65 centimeter squared and a mean gradient of 29 mmHg. She is now admitted for elective aortic valve replacement and coronary artery bypass graft.

Initially, this is a 29  week gestation, mono-mono twin #1, delivered preterm by C section due to premature rupture of membrane. Mother was a 28 year old gravida 2, para 0 to 2, female with an unremarkable prenatal screen. The GBS was unknown. There was a mono-mono diabetes treated with Insulin. The mother did note epigastric pain prior to delivery which prompted her to come to the hospital for evaluation. Ultrasound was reassuring with biophysical profile of 8 and 8. She was treated with betamethasone and that was completed on . She was, also at the time noted to be hypertensive and started on Labetalol. She remained in house; then on the morning of delivery, spontaneous rupture of membranes occurred and there was therefore delivery by C section because of concern regarding a cord accident in the setting of a monoamnion. This twin emerged with spontaneous cry requiring facial CPAP and routine care in the Delivery Room. Apgars were 8 and 8 and the baby was transferred to the NICU on CPAP for further evaluation and management of prematurity.

She was seen in the ATU the next day where the pain resolved but she was noted to be contracting. Ultrasound was reassuring with biophysical profile of 8 and 8. The baby was transferred to the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit for further evaluation and management of prematurity.

The following is a summary of events of his hospital stay up until transfer to  (bulleted for ease of summarizing

64M with h/o AF, DM and HTN and no h/o CAD or CHF, which was originally admitted to  on  with dyspnea. He had been experiencing chills, dry cough, and low-grade fever during the previous week. He also did admit an increase in his intake of salty food. On , he became more dyspneic. He became frightened, and attempted to drive himself to the hospital, whereupon he had an MVA with a stationary object and hit his head. Afterwards c/o neck pain attributed to whiplash. In the ED, he was febrile to 101.5F, with CXR demonstrating cardiomegaly, perihilar vascular congestion and possible R infiltrate. A subsequent CTA was negative for PE, though was a limited study, and extensive airspace disease was seen c/w ARDS vs PNA vs CHF. Rapid flu A/B was negative. He was also noted to have RLE cellulitis which, per the family, has been present for at least 5 years, and LENIs were checked, which were negative for DVT. He was in AF with rate in the 80s, with a rate-dependent LBBB. Head CT reportedly showed no evidence of hemorrhage. . On the medical floor, he was started on CTX and Azithro, which was changed to Levofloxacin. He experienced worsening tachycardia and intermittent hypotension. CKs were elevated to 300s with negative MBs. Troponin was initially 0.01, peaked at 0.11 on , and decreased to 0.07, with positive being >0.30. He was transiently on a heparin gtt during ROMI. Repeat CXR demonstrated progressive infiltrates, and pt became increasingly hypoxic. He was intubated on , and diuresed  concerns about CHF. He was transiently on neosynephrine for hypotension. A TTE was done, demonstrated mildly reduced LV function with septal paradox, mild-mod reduced RV function of unclear etiology, and evidence of caval plethora, though pt was on PEEP. Initial ddx for these findings included pulmonary HTN with decompensated RV or possible myocardial contusion from the MVA. He was extubated without difficulty after 36 hours, and was satting well on 2L NC, but found to have striking delirium. He was treated acutely with Haldol and benzodiazepines, with some effect. He continued to be hypertensive to 180s, and with worsening radiographic CXR findings in spite of clinical improvement. At some point in stay, antibiotic regimen changed to Levofloxacin/Vanc. Also with rising transaminitis with AST/ALT in 500s at time of transfer. In the context of fever and mental status changes, consideration was given to performing LP; however, due to inadequate neurology coverage at , pt was transferred to  for further evaluation. . On arrival, initial labs significant for hypernatremia of 154, hypokalemia at 3.3, BUN/Cr 32/1.5, INR 5.4. Initial CEs CK 117(3), trop 0.07. ALT 469, AST 116, Aphos 56, Tbili 2.3, Amylase 162, Lipase 216.

This is a 44 year old male with a past medical history significant for multiple medical problems including coronary artery disease, status post four vessel coronary artery bypass graft, atrial fibrillation on Coumadin, end stage renal disease on hemodialysis, diabetes mellitus, and left embolic middle cerebral artery cerebrovascular accident, who presents from nursing home with hypotension and bright red blood per rectum. Per nursing home report, the patient had a one day history of dark red blood per rectum. He was incontinence of stool and stool amount was unable to further be quantified. His blood pressure dropped to the 80s systolic and he was also noted to be febrile to 102.0. No abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting or hematemesis was noted. The patient had been noted to have a recent INR of 1.6 to 1.8 with a hematocrit of 25, down from his baseline of 29. Upon arrival in the Emergency Department, the patient was tachycardiac with heart rate in the 120s to 140s with a rhythm of atrial fibrillation. His systolic blood pressure was in the 100s. His hematocrit was 27.5 and his INR was 2.0. Soon after arrival to the Emergency Department he had two episodes of dark red blood per rectum with subsequent drops in his blood pressure to a systolic of 70s to 80s. He received 1 liter of normal saline and 2 units of packed red blood cells. He also received 30 ml of Proplex to reverse his INR, in addition to 10 mg subcutaneous Vitamin K. Proplex was chosen given the patient's anuric end stage renal disease and concern for volume overload. The patient also received Protonix 40 mg intravenously. Following volume resuscitation his blood pressure increased to 110 systolic. He had an nasogastric lavage which showed no evidence of blood or clot. The patient was then admitted to the Medicine Intensive Care Unit for further management.

HPI: Pt is a 43 yo female with a h/o LBP (thoracic and diffuse lumbar)after a bus accident in , who presents with acute mental status change, fever, agitation, and increasing lower back pain. She originally was brought to her PCP office by her partner on  after worsening LBP and fever and new onset rambling tangential speech, agitation, confusion, and tremors. PCP sent her to  ED. VS upon presentation 101.2, 141/87, 99%RA and noted to be diffusely flushed and tachycardic. She was given 1L NS, ceftriaxone 2g IV x1, and valium 5mg IV x1. Neurologic exam was nonfocal but limited secondary to pain. DDx was NMS, meningitis, TCA toxicity secondary to flexeril or compazine, or epidural abscess. ECG was within normal limits with exception of sinus tachycardia, no QRS widening suggesting TCA toxicity. She was transferred to  ED for toxicology evaluation, MRI and neurologic evaluation secondary to there being no unit beds at . . Upon arrival to , Tmax 103.8, tachycardia persisted and BP ranged 115/72-153/102. She received 3L NS and 1g vancomycin IV. Acyclovir IV was also ordered for concern of herpes encephalitis but it is not clear if this was administered. Given serum tox screen positive for TCAs, 2mg physostigmine IV was administered for concern of anticholinergic overdose without change in mental status. Attempts at MRI initially failed due to agitation despite 4mg ativan IV; pt was intubated for sedation. She received 20mg IV etomidate, 120mg IV succinylcholine, and propofol gtt. MRI revealed a right psoas abscess extending into the epidural space. She was admitted to  spine for emergent drainage. Underwent laminectomy of L3-4 with drainage of nonpurulent material.

The patient is a 41 year-old Portuguese speaking gentleman who was transferred here from  Hospital status post an motor vehicle accident. On postoperative day one he turned head to examiner. Pupils on the right was 3 down to 2.5, the left 2.5 down to 2 and moving all extremities spontaneously and withdrew to pain times four. He was extubated. He was given platelets to keep his platelet count above 75. He was given fresh frozen platelets to keep his INR less then 1.3. His vital signs remained stable. He had a repeat head CT, which showed good evacuation of the subdural hematoma. He was transferred to the regular floor on  and continued on Ativan for alcohol withdraw precautions. Slowly his neurological status improved where he was more awake following simple commands although there was a language barrier.

The patient was found to have left distal radial and proximal fibular fractures and was recommended nonsurgical management by Orthopedics and Plastic Services. The patient was to be discharged on , however, that evening he underwent an acute desaturation to 84% on his nasal cannulas which then increased to 93% on a nonrebreather mask. The patient had a temperature of 100.4 orally, coarse rhonchi and the blood pressure was stable. An arterial blood gases was done which showed 7.33/47/59. There were no changes on the electrocardiogram. The patient stopped intravenous fluids and got 10 mg of intravenous Lasix times three and put out 500 cc of urine output. The patient was transferred to the Post Anesthesia Care Unit and went into atrial fibrillation which he has a history of proximal atrial fibrillation in the rates of 120 to 130s and the blood pressure remained normotensive. He was started on a Nitro drip, Morphine Sulfate, Lopressor and white blood cell count then went up to 17.2. The patient then became hypoxic on 100% nonrebreather and was intubated in the Trauma Surgery Intensive Care Unit and then transferred to the Medicine Intensive Care Unit. The patient got a chest computerized tomography scan which was consistent with a pneumonia and no pulmonary embolism. He was started on Propofol for intubation at that time and his systolic blood pressure decreased in the 70s. His temperature was 101 and with a white blood cell count of 17.2 there was concern that the patient was in septic ,  he was started on a Neo-Synephrine drip at 3 mcg/kg/min. The patient was swanned with a central venous pressure of 12, pulmonary artery pressure of 30/15 and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 15/16.

28yo female unrestrained driver s/p car-on-car collision w/+LOC. Reported GCS of 12 in field. Transported via  after delayed extracation requiring jaws of life. Stable on arrival to  ED with GCS of 15. Complaining of diffuse pain throughout head/neck/chest and abdomen.

33 year-old healthy male with a long history of lower extremity edema and intermittent erythema who presents to the ED after a motor vehicle accident. According to te patient, his fiancee, and his mother, he was feeling well up until earlier today when his left leg became painful and erythematous. He remembers getting in his car to drive somewhere, and then his next memory is of walking around after the accident. He reportedly was the restrained driver in a motor vehicle accident in which his vehicle hit a tree or a pole. . He was thoroughly evaluated in the ED for any evidence of traumatic injury, and had negative films including a chest x-ray, pelvis films, and left knee films. He had CT scans of the head, C-spine, and entire Torso that did not show any evidence of traumatic inhury, fracture, source of infection, or bone abnormality. On arrival he was noted to be febrile to 104.8, tachycardic, and hypotensive at one point with a blood pressure of 93 systolic. His exam in the ED was remarkable for bbilateral lower extremity edema, and for mild erythema of the left lower leg with leg tenderness. A left lower extremity doppler study showed no evidence for DVT. . An attempt was made at an LP, but the procedure was unable to be completed. Given the patient's high fever, altered mental status, and leukocytosis he was treated for both cellulitis and meningitis. His other labs were notable for a normal urinalysis without any blood or protein, a normal serum sodium, and a normal BUN/Creatinine of 19/1.9. His serum toxicology screen was negative as well. . On further historical review, his fiancee and mother state that he has had lower extremity edema since age 5. This has always fluctuated, but has never disappeared. He has also had the erythema of the left leg twice in the past, and he has been treated with naproxen and antibiotics for presumed cellulitis. The erythema usually lasts for a week, and it never goes above the knee. There is no history of skin breakdown or subcutaneous nodules. However, he reports having occasional skin blisters when his edema is severe. he has no history of hematuria, dysuria, sore throat, cough, SOB, DOE, orthopnea, rash, eye inflammation, urehtral inflammation, joint pains or swelling, and he has not had any easy bruising, prolonged bleeding, or blood clots. . His medical history is significant for only his chronic lower extremity edema. He has no PCP,  was previously treated for similar left leg symptoms and fever at  Hospital ED. he has a known right Bell's Palsy, and possibly a history of a left Bell's Palsy 5 years ago.

A 71-year-old man status post a motor vehicle accident related to syncope on  without injuries from the motor vehicle accident. However, he was admitted to  following the accident and a workup revealed 3 vessel disease.

The patient is a 76-year-old woman who was a struck at a low speed motor vehicle collision of a vehicle versus pedestrian. She has suffered from a nondisplaced occipital fracture with a small right temporal subdural. She has evidence of pneumocephalus during the initial trauma on her first CT scan. Her head CT was stable from initial trauma and neurologic exam is stable. Subsequently, she was transferred to the Step Down and developed change in mental status. Initial cultures were negative. with persistent fever, she was again pancultured and lumbar puncture was performed. The lumbar puncture revealed significant elevated white count. She was subsequently treated for meningitis and brought to the ICU. ID consult was obtained. She was aggressively treated and intubated in the ICU for bacterial meningitis. Cultures were negative but profile suggestive of meningitis. With discussion with her family DNR/DNI status was instituted.

yo F unrestrained passenger s/p motor vehicle crash with possible LOC who presented to  ED confused, found to have sternal fracture, pneumomediastinum and anterior mediastinal hematoma, left rib fractures, and bilateral pelvic fractures.

The patient is a pleasant -year-old female who was an unrestrained driver involved in a motor vehicle collision going approximately 50 miles per hour. The patient rear-ended a stopped car. Positive airbag deployment. The patient denies hitting her head and denies loss of consciousness. The patient's right knee hit the dashboard, and the patient complained of right knee pain. The patient was taken to an outside hospital emergency room where she had x-rays done which showed a right proximal tibia fracture. The patient received a chest x-ray which was read as negative and a pelvic film which was read as negative. The patient's cervical spine films, three views, cleared the cervical spine per report. The patient was without complaints of neck pain and was hemodynamically stable. Also per report, the patient had faint palpable pulses to the bilateral femoral artery. No posterior tibial pulses bilaterally. Bilateral Dopplerable pulses to the dorsalis pedis and bilateral legs which were cold to touch. Patient without any motor or sensory loss. The patient also complained of right upper quadrant pain. The patient denies any chest pain, dizziness or light-headedness. Patient with GCS of 15 at outside facility.

This is a 68 year old gentleman with a history of Parkinson's disease and a recent prolonged complicated admission, status post motor vehicle accident where he was hit by a car as a pedestrian who returned with fever, shortness of breath and hypotension from rehabilitation. He was admitted on  to  after being struck by a car. In that admission he had a complicated course including a right fibular fracture and right acetabular fracture and multiple left rib fractures and left perisplenic hematoma and left common femoral vein deep vein thrombosis and had a inferior vena cava filter placed on . He also had evidence of right lower extremity skin necrosis in the thigh and cellulitis which was debrided and had a skin graft from his thigh. Also during that hospitalization, he had an exploratory laparotomy which showed left retroperitoneal, perinephric hematoma, also complicated by pancreatitis status post endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography and sphincterotomy and Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia which was treated with Vancomycin. He was discharged on  to . He was there two to three days prior to representation at . He developed fevers, tachypnea and shortness of breath at that rehabilitation and was sent back in for further evaluation. On admission he had evidence of a right lower lobe pneumonia. He was started on Flagyl for concern for aspiration pneumonia. He was given a dose of Azotreanam at the rehabilitation and was started on Vancomycin given his history of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

26 y.o. female involved in MVC. Pt was restrained passenger in rollover with +LOC. Transferred to another hospital where pt had CT of C-spine revealing C1, C3, and C7 fractures. Then transferred to  for further care.

The patient was an unrestrained SUV driver involved in a rollover MVA, ejection 30-40 feet. Loss of consciousness at scene but GCS 15 thereafter. The patient admitted to the ICU in light of possibly unstable crit in the setting of numerous fractures, and peritoneal hematoma.

This is a 19-year-old male, status post motor vehicle collision. The patient was an unrestrained passenger who states that he was passed out in the car prior to the crash due to alcohol ingestion that evening. He was ambulating at the scene with a GCS of 15 and taken to  complaining of neck pain. The patient was found to have a C2 fracture and transferred to . The patient is a 29 year old man who was admitted through the emergency room on , after he had a motor vehicle accident while riding on his motorcycle. He was rear-ended on the afternoon before admission and was thrown forward, apparently hitting the windshield of the car in front of him. He did not remember actually hitting the windshield. He remembered stinging in his neck and his feet and was taken to an outside emergency department where a C-spine film was performed that showed no fracture. He went home with a cervical collar, but after falling asleep that night, he was awakened by the sudden onset of a golfball-like sensation in his lower back and sudden weakness and numbness in his left leg that happened very suddenly. He also had weakness in his right leg and numbness of his right thigh which progressed more slowly than the left. He could not feel his bowel movements or the urge to urinate and had incontinence of both urine and feces.

This is a 73 year old male pedestrian struck by a car with  Coma Scale of 3 at the scene. There at the scene, he was intubated and brought to the Emergency Room. The patient was hemodynamically stable upon arrival and was otherwise unresponsive.

Mrs.  is an 80 year old unfortunate woman who was an unrestrained back seat passenger in an SUV sustaining a motor vehicle accident. This is a 55 year old man with a history of hypertension and EtOH abuse who presented to the emergency department after a car vs. telephone pole low speed collision. He had been drinking in association with the   Cup victory of the  Bruins, was driving, got distracted by changing the radio station, and ran into a telephone pole. Airbag was deployed. He was reportedly wearing a seatbelt. He denied loss of consciousness. . On arrival in ED, VS 80/palp 84 12 100% had +ETOH (86). Also noted were anemia (23), hypokalemia (1.7), renal failure (3.9) and hypophosphatemia (0.6) of unclear chronicity. Patient received potassium repletion (40) and 4L NS. Patient noted recent diarrhea, no fevers/chills/nausea/chills. He was pan scanned, only showing non-displaced rib fractures (R ). He was admitted to TSICU for monitoring. . Patient was given phosphate and IV fluid overnight, with his creatinine, phos, K improving. The surgical team requested transfer to medicine for further w/u of anemia, electolyte abnormalities and possible EtOH withdrawal. Phosphate was 1.0 at the time of transfer, and the surgical team was administering IV phosphate before transfer. . At the time of transfer, he was well. He reported no pain, nor tremor or anxiety. He reported that his last drink was approximately a day and a half prior. He has no pain, and he does not feel shaky or anxious. His last drink was 36 hours ago. Patient has no history of withdrawal seizures, hallucinosis or delirium tremens.

32M + EtOH s/p high speed ATV collision this. Friends report found patient beside a tree, disoriented and unconscious. Upon EMS arrival he was intubated at scene and evaluated at  hospital. CT head showing frontal and temporal IPH; he was transferred to  for further care.

25 year old male presented as a transfer status post rollover motor vehicle crash and ejection with stable, non-operative spleen and kidney lacs, bilateral Pneumothoraces status post bilateral chest tubes and intubation at an outside hospital.

The patient is a 66-year-old female who is transferred from an OSH after an MVC in which she was a restrained driver and rear-ended. Her workup from an OSH is negative aside from a large right breast hematoma.

The patient was a trauma transfer from an outside hospital. This is a 59 year old male, five days status post motorcycle accident, at 40 mph, who initially had no loss of consciousness at the scene. He was wearing a helmet. He was found to have bilateral intraparenchymal bleeds but was awake, alert and oriented times three. His chest and abdomen CT examinations were negative. His pelvis films were negative. His films of his left femur were also negative. He was brought to  secondary to the reason he had experienced bilateral upper extremity weakness and was found to have had a T7 compression fracture prior to transfer. He was transferred via  from  Hospital to  with this T7 compression fracture as well as the T4 compression fracture with pressure upon his cord. The patient was intubated previous to transfer. He arrived at  paralyzed and sedated on the vent.

This is a 17 year old female status post motor vehicle accident with a grade III splenic laceration seen at  and transported by ground EMS to  Emergency Department. Pole snapped, airbag deployed, moderate damage to car. The patient denied striking head, no loss of consciousness, no neck pain, complaining only of abdominal pain. The patient was nauseated and vomited one time. Last menstrual period was two weeks ago. The patient was unable to be transported by helicopter secondary to thunder showers.

Patient dropped off her 3yo child at daycare. Got back into the car (driver) and noticed a spider on her shirt. She opened the door to get rid of the spider. She lost her balance falling on her left side. The car at that point rolled over her. She cannot remember the exact location of the roll and is not sure whether she had abdominal trauma. She was the only one in the car. Denies hitting her head. . Presently reports pain mostly over left side. "face feels swollen and funny." Denies dizziness, chest pain, palpitations. Denies vaginal bleeding or leaking of fluid. Feeling fetal movement.  contractions. Reports minimal abdominal pain.

24F unrestrained driver of car s/p collision with tree. +ETOH; reportedly was not moving her legs at the scene, was intubated and taken to an area hospital. CT imaging done there showed SDH and SAH; she was loaded with dilantin and medflighted to  for further care.

This is a 72-year-old male status post motor vehicle collision, restrained driver, who was hit on the driver's side. No loss of consciousness. The patient starred windshield, deployed air bag. Pt is a 19 year old male unrestrained driver who presented via  from a high-speed MVA. Pt had a GCS of 7 and was intubated at the scene. HD stable on transfer.

Patient is a 57F  to  on  after being pedestrian struck by car on , sustaining multiple orthopedic injuries, requiring surgical fixation. The patient is a 20 year old female pedestrian struck by a car while crossing Route 128. She was found unresponsive on the scene and intubated in the field. Her  coma scale was 4 in the field. 78f s/p head-on MVC, restrained passenger,+EtOH,30 mph with extensive front end damage & deployment of airbag, GCS 15, complain of chest pain/back pain. The patient is a 25-year-old man who was an unrestrained driver in an SUV that hit the median at moderate speed. The patient's airbag deployed and the patient was ambulating at the scene. EMS transported the patient to the  Trauma Bay in stable condition.

This  hospital admission with a 72 year-old woman who was reportedly struck by a motor vehicle with front end damage and window. The window shield was intact. She was noted to have head, chest and pelvic trauma and bilateral lower leg fractures with an open on the left.

The patient is a 50-year-old-male unrestrained driver who hit a tree at high speeds and was ejected from the vehicle. He was seen at an outside hospital and there was concern for a small pseudoaneurysm of aortic arch. He was transferred to  for further care.

53 yo F s/p MVA - vehicle vs telphone pole. Car noted by observer to be weaving prior to collision. +LOC. Became combative. GCS . Pt was intubated at the scene. No known injuries but hypertensive at scene. FAST neg. +Etoh/cocaine.

This patient is a 31 year old female who complains of ABDOMINAL PAIN S/P MVC. 31 yr old woman rear seat passenger in mvc restrained struck another vehicle, head on, airbags, and windshield broken. Nausea no vomiting.
71 yo male pedestrian struck by auto as he was crossing street; vehicle at unknown speed taken to area hospital for obvious left leg deformity; stabilized and transferred to  for trauma care.

Mr.  is a 52 year old man who was a pedestrian struck at moderate speed by car - pt denies LOC. Per EMS - car w/ significant damage. He has c/o left upper extremity pain, left knee pain. He was transported to the  for further care

Patient is a 60 year old male who was a driver in the moderate speed accident, the MVC vs. tree. He was taken to the OSH and on CT a/p was found to have free intraperitoneal fluid. He was transferred to us via . His HCT has dropped from 30 to 22 upon arrival here. He was GCS 15 upon arrival, then intubated in the ED for airway protection. The FAST was positive in the ED and the CT from OSH was suspicious for mesenteric bleed.

s/p MVC from likely syncopal episode, hit another car & water hydrant. Does not recall events of accident but all events prior to and afterwards. GCS 15 from  Hospital and on arrival here. He has multiple traumatic injuries including hemoperitoneum w/ liver lac of L lobe & active extravasation and widening of the anterior C2/3 and C3/4 intervertebral space w/ posterior osteophyte C4/5, causing mild-to-moderate canal narrowing. This is a 22 year old male who was the unrestrained driver in a motor vehicle accident. The patient was found at the scene unresponsive in the back seat of the car. The pt is a 65y/o man with a history of HLD and Hypothyroidism who presents to  ED with a seizure intubated in the field. He was at work today (landscaper) driving his truck when he made a left hand turn and did not stop turning left and then crashed. When EMS arrived he was alert and talking and then he started to have a generalized convulsive seizure with witnessed left gaze deviation. he was intubated and taken to the ED. Here he was seen intubated on midazolam and fentanyl. His wife who is at the bedside notes that he was generally healthy and has not been complaining of anything and has never noted any seizure like activity including any behavioral arrest.

The patient is a 39 year old male pedestrian struck after a convenience store robbery by an automobile. He had a GCS of 3 at the scene. This is a 22 year old male trauma patient, pedestrian struck by a car and found unresponsive/apneic in the field where he was intubated and brought to . Exact details of the situation

43M transferred from another facility following patient being involved in an ATV crash vs auto. 44 year old male status post high speed T-bone motor vehicle accident. He was unrestrained and found  partially out of the driver-side window. He was intoxicated and had a GCS of 14 at the scene. 25 yo male s/p MVC rollover, unresponsive at scene, +ETOH. Failed attempts to intubate on the scene. Temporary airway placed and pt brought to ED.

Mr.  is a 17-year-old young man who was involved in a roll-over motor vehicle crash on . He was restrained and the motor vehicle collision involved airbag deployment. There was prolonged extrication reported to be approximately 20 minutes. His  Coma Scale was 3 initially at the scene. He was subsequently taken to . At  his GCS was 6. He was combative, rapid sequence induction was performed, and he was intubated at . Bilateral chest tubes were placed for a right pneumothorax and left hemothorax. He was subsequently transferred via LifeFlight ground due to high wind to . On arrival, Mr.  heart rate was 140, blood pressure was 120/palpable and his heart rate continued to climb to 160. In the trauma bay Mr.  received four units of packed red blood cells. His endotracheal tube was advanced. A 36 French left chest tube was placed for persistent hemothorax. A diagnostic peritoneal lavage was performed which was positive by visual inspection and he was subsequently taken to the operating room urgently for an exploratory laparotomy.

This is a 35 year-old male admitted on  status post motor vehicle accident head on collision, unrestrained driver with positive loss of consciousness, no air bag deployment. 63yM restrained driver moderate speed with airbag deployment, -LOC, R chest ecchymosis and mediastinal hematoma found on CT scan at referring hospital.

This is a 22 year-old female who was struck by a car. She was unsure whether she lost consciousness. She was hemodynamically stable at the scene and en route to the hospital. She complained of head and hip pain.

This is a 22 year old female pedestrian struck by car and thrown greater than thirty feet. There was significant front end damage to the car with the windshield smashed. This is a 19-year-old unrestrained driver with question loss of consciousness in a high speed rollover motor vehicle crash transferred from  Hospital.  coma score was 15. Hemodynamically stable. Noted to have a L1 burst fracture on CT scan, complains of back pain.

27 y/o female who was in high speed MVA. Positive LOC. Positive ejection from vehicle. Transfered from OSH. En route GCS 15 and hemodynamically stable. The patient was complaining of RUQ and RLE tenderness.

44 yo male driver s/p motor vehicle crash; reportedly his brakes locked and his car spun out of control and hit a pole. + brief LOC. Per EMS reports GCS 15. He was transported via  to  for managment of his severe injuries.

53F brought to  ED via ambulance as pedestrian struck by a car, +EtOH, +LOC. Upon arrival to  ED, the patient was found to be extremetly agitated and combative. She did not give a history and did not endorse any particular pain. She did complain of shortness of breath.

66M s/p rollover MVC. Per report, patient was the restrained passenger. Unclear LOC or whether airbags were deployed. There was prolonged extrication time at the scene. The patient was intubated for airway protection without difficulty. . In the ED, FAST exam was negative. 20 yo M s/p MVC with prolonged extrication, had posterior hip dislocation which was reduced in the ED. Intubated for combative behavior.

The patient is a 34-year-old male who was a helmeted motorcycle rider who missed a turn on the highway and crashed into a side rail. The patient was found facedown with positive loss of consciousness. When EMS arrived, the patient awoke and was complained of back and chest pain.

31 M HIV+ s/p motor vehicle crash vs tree + LOC, GCS 14 at scene, intubated for combativeness with multiple discrete foci of hemorrhagic contusion and tiny left subdural hemorrhage. He was transported to  for further care.

Patient is an 18 year old who fell from a motor bike after making a jump off a ramp. 85F, transferred from  s/p MVC. Per EMS report, she was restrained passenger in back seat of vehicle and collision occurred on pt's side of vehicle. Pt experienced LOC briefly. CT head showed small intracranial hemorrhage and she is tx for further evaluation.

The patient is a 41-year-old gentleman involved in a high-speed motor cycle versus pavement accident on  and was found 24 ft from the bike. He was transported to  but was unable to be intubated in the field. Heart rate was in the 60s, and he was hypotensive. On arrival, his GCS goal was 3T.

This is a 50 year old female who was brought in by EMS after a syncopal episode leading to a head-on collision against a tree at approximately 30 mph. The patient was restrained and the airbag deployed. The patient was hemodynamically stable with a GCS of 15 in the Emergency Department. In the Emergency Department, she was complaining of left chest pain, shortness of breath, and in the field left crepitus was noted as well. In the trauma bay, the patient was hemodynamically stable with a GCS of 15, however, her oxygen saturation rate initially was between 80 and 90%. It was also noted at that time that her breath sounds on the left side were markedly decreased. A tube thoracostomy was then performed on the left side without complications. After the placement of the tube thoracostomy, the patient's oxygen saturation rate improved to 97%, her shortness of breath improved, and lung sounds improved on the left side as well. She remained hemodynamically stable throughout the procedure and tolerated it well. As far as her syncopal episode that led to the accident, the patient reports feeling lightheaded and then blacked out and woke up immediately after her motor vehicle collision without any confusion, no loss of continence, and denied symptoms of chest pain, palpitations, diaphoresis, or headache. She also notes the use of cocaine three days prior to the accident, and previously, one year ago without any sequelae at that time. She had one previous episode of syncope during pregnancy. There is no history of syncope in her family, but there is a significant history of myocardial infarction, both in her father and mother at an early age.

The patient is a 52-year-old man status post crush injury to bilateral thighs. He had positive loss of consciousness. He was an unrestrained passenger in a bus accident with a prolonged extrication time. He was hemodynamically stable in the field and received 1 L Crystalloid. He was transferred via  to  and given Ancef in the Emergency Department.

57 yo male pedestrian who was struck by tractor trailer. Per EMS report his GCS 3 on scene, he was intubated and medflighted to  for further care; the patient was found decerebrate posturing and seizing in the field. ETOH level noted to be 171 in the Emergency room.

is a 23 year-old gentleman who was in a high speed motor vehicle collision with rollover and subsequent submersion into water on  of . 21 yo female unrestriend driver, s/p high speed motor vehicle crash vs. tree. + EtOH; + LOC with prolonged extrication. Transported to ED; combative upon arrival requiring increased doses of sedatives.

29yo male s/p MVC vs pole after rear-tire blowout. Transferred from  hospital for CT cspine findings of type II dens fracture. no deficits or other injuries.

Mr.  is a 17-year-old unrestrained driver of a car who hit a tree at approximately 70 miles per hour. He was ejected from a vehicle and was emergently transferred to  Hospital. He was found to have   Coma Scale of 3. At  Hospital, intravenous access was achieved and the patient was intubated. In the trauma bay at , Mr.  received bilateral chest tubes, diagnostic peritoneal lavage which was negative, emergent stapling of a bleeding forehead laceration and tightening of pelvis. Portable films were obtained in the trauma room and from the trauma room the patient was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit for further stabilization.

25-year-old female status post motor vehicle collision BIBA complaining of chest and left ankle pain. Patient denied any LOC but complained of sternal, right-sided chest and mild epigastric pain. Transported hemodynamically stable to ED. Her work up revealed a grade I splenic and hepatic lacerations with minimal blood around the spleen. The patient was admitted to the TSICU for serial exams and blood work.

Mr.  is a 25yo unrestrained male driver of minivan involved in T-bone mvc vs truck with body found to be against passenger side window (where most damage was found), unresponsive. The patient is a 49 year old male who presented to  as a basic trauma via  following a high speed motor vehicle collision versus telephone pole. He was intubated and transferred from OSH with depressed skull fracture, SVT, and obvious right tib/fib fractures.

17yo M unrestrained driver involved in MVC, found by EMS at scene unresponsive and pulseless and apneic for an unknown period of time. Resuscitated with Atropine and Epinephrine with establishment of pulse, subsequently intubated and brought to nearest hospital. At OSH he arrested, and revived with atropine and epinephrine. This is a 28 year old female admitted on  who came to the Emergency Room on the same date who was a restrained back-seat passenger involved in a motor vehicle accident. There was no loss of consciousness. Her GCS was 15. On route, she developed some abdominal pain when transported by EMS. The patient is Haitian and French-only speaking and there was initial confusion as to her symptoms when using family as an interpreter. The trauma system was not activated. The patient was hemodynamically stable without any tachycardia throughout her visit. She complained of pain with movement, but she had no nausea, vomiting, shortness of breath, or chest pain. The CT was performed which showed free fluid and thickening of the small bowel and transverse colon and a boggy uterus. LMP of one month ago. Given the patient's last menstrual period, TVUS of one month ago a normal right ovary, and TVUS was performed demonstrating a normal right ovary and uterus as well as the free fluid. The left ovary was not seen. At this point, a trauma surgery consult was obtained.

26 yo woman s/p high speed MVC; restrained passenger in pickup truck head on collision; prolonged extrication; GCS ~11 at OSH, intubated for  with report of not protecting airway. Obvious head injury. + cocaine, marijuana, amphetamines on OSH tox screen.

This is an 84 year old female involved in a motor vehicle accident, low speed. She was a restrained driver.  coma scale is 15. No loss of consciousness. She was transferred from an outside hospital complaining of right chest pain and right rib pain, no shortness of breath and no dizziness.

64 year old male pedestrian who was crushed under his car at low speed. No reported LOC. He was transported from the scene directly to the  emergency room.

This is a 32 yo man previously healthy, who is s/p MVC on (car vs pole) -unrestrained driver, ETOH+ . He was ejected from the vehicle and apparently struck his head, sustaining multiple injuries, He was found on the scene unresponsive with fixed/dilated pupils and asystolic per first responders. He underwent CPR for unknown period of time, was intubated, and initially was taken to  Hosp. There, he had a rhythm but was hypotensive. He was transferred to  ostensibly for neurosurgical eval. On study he was found to have SAH as well as SDH and diffuse cerebral edema. He had a C1 subluxation with posterior displacement and a high spinal cord injury. On initial exam here he had fixed/dilated pupils, no corneal reflexes, no response to noxious stimulation and was areflexic with mute Babinski's.

This is a 31 year old female who was in a motor vehicle collision, a car versus tree. She was the unrestrained driver of the vehicle and was found at the scene with   Coma Scale of 3. She was unable to be intubated in the field and she was transferred to an outside hospital where the patient was intubated. She had a hypotensive episode of a systolic blood pressure down to 80 requiring four liters of Crystalloid and one unit of packed red blood cells.

37 yo F thrown off motorcycle, helmeted with helmet intact, LOC unknown but combative with all 4 extremities at time of arrival of EMS, GCS E4M5V4 @1.35AM. Vital signs stable, has been able to maintain own airways open with sufficient respiratory drive. 2.30AM GCS E4M6V4, infused with 2L NS and 1L RL. +Etoh. No pain medications administered.

The patient is a 33-year-old male in a motor vehicle  evading the police. The patient went off the road and was thrown from the vehicle about 60 ft. The patient was moving all extremities purposefully at the scene and was given .................. and intubated at the scene secondary to agitation.

This is a 70 year old male who was a crossing guard who got struck by a motor vehicle. The patient was thrown 30 to 35 feet and had positive loss of consciousness. He had a laceration to the right side of his head which was sutured in the outside hospital. At the outside hospital he was noted to have a depressed first rib fracture on computerized tomography scan with associated hematoma in the area of the aorta. He was transferred to  for further management. The  coma scale at the outside hospital was 15.

The patient is a 24-year-old male with no significant past medical history who on  was riding on his motorcycle which was hit by a car. He was found to be unconscious at the scene with a GCS of 3. He was hemodynamically stable on arrival to the ER and was emergently taken to the OR.
59 yo male pedestrina who was struck by auto @~20-30 mph; no reported LOC. He was transported from scene to  for further care.

HPI:19 yr old male unrestrained driver s/p car vs tree at reported high rate of speed. Per reports pt has not moved his lower extremities. Pt brought from scene to  for further evaluation. Pt was paralyzed, sedated and intubated in the trauma bay upon arrival.

This is a 44 year old male with past medical history of polysubstance abuse who was an unrestrained passenger in a high speed motor vehicle collision who was transferred from an outside hospital. Pt is well known to this service s/p MVA  and craniectomy. Returns for elective cranioplasty.

Mr.  is a 68 y/o male who was "T" boned, struck on drivers side, by a car at an unknown speed, requiring prolonged extraction with Jaws of Life. The patient is a 19-year-old female who was an unrestrained driver of a truck, which rolled over and resulted in substantial multiple injuries in . Mr.  is a 46 year old male s/p 3 vehicle rollover collision. He was a restrained driver and denied LOC. Initial GCG was 15. The patient presented with multiple deformities of the lower extremities bilaterally and a laceration to the right side of the head.

Mr.  is a 56 year old gentleman who was involved in a single car motor vehicle collision with a tree on the day of admission. He was a restrained driver. Upon arrival, a CT scan revealed fractures of C1, C2, C3, and C4 with significant cord compromise. He was admitted to the TSICU where he was subsequently seen by trauma orthopedics, trauma spine and neurosurgery.

26 yo male unrestrained passenger in a multi-car accident, ejected 100 feet from vehicle, found in . He was transferred from  Hospital in critical condition reported to have liver laceration, pulmonary contusion, fractured ribs, broken arm, hypotensive and hypoxic.

59 y/o male, unrestrained driver, high speed MVC car vs. pole. GCS 5 in field, so patient intubated. Found to have bilateral small apical ptx, rib fx, pelvic fs, SAH/SDH, facial fx, depressed skull fx L parietal area.

is a 21-year-old male driver, who apparently had a witnessed seizure and drove his car into a guardrail. He was unrestrained. He was taken to an outside hospital, where a CT scan showed a right basal ganglia bleed. He was therefore transferred to  for further evaluation and treatment.
