The patient is a 22 year old male, status post motor vehicle collision, the patient fell asleep at the wheel, was an unrestrained driver. The motor vehicle had turned over and the patient arrived with a GCS of 15. On arrival, the patient was tachycardic and hypotensive and given six liters of crystalloid and brought to the CT scanner after response to fluids. The patient sustained a grade III/IV splenic laceration, small left pneumothorax, pulmonary contusions, left rib fractures of ribs eight, nine and ten, small pelvic rami superior and inferior fracture with intramuscular hematoma. The patient's official CT read showed a splattered spleen with hemoperitoneum, grade III/IV splenic laceration, the hilum appeared to be intact.

The patient is a 22-year-old gentleman involved in a high-speed motor vehicle crash with positive loss of consciousness at the scene. The patient had   Coma Scale of 3 at the scene and was intubated by emergency personnel.

The patient is a 37 year old male who was in a motorcycle accident versus car, helmeted with no loss of consciousness, going approximately 40 mph. The patient was complaining at the scene of left leg pain, left chest pain. The patient was med-flighted and on route had one episode of a systolic blood pressure in the 80s that responded to fluid. The patient was back-boarded and cervical collared at the scene. GCS was 15.

The patient was admitted on , who is a 58-year-old gentleman who was an unrestrained driver car versus tree, who sustained a C2-C3 subluxation as well as a right acetabular fracture with posterior dislocation and a positive peroneal nerve injury. Patient was transferred to  for care.

This is a 65 year old pedestrian who was struck by a car was found asystolic and unresponsive in the field, full ACLS code was run and he was intubated and brought to  after return of pulse. At  computerized tomography scan of the head, chest x-ray and pelvis films were done with severe head injury noted, positive subarachnoid hemorrhage, epidural parenchymal bleed reported by head computerized tomography scan. He was given Mannitol and transferred to  with stable vital signs throughout his transit. He was given no sedation or paralytic at  or in transit.

The patient is a 48-year-old woman who was a pedestrian hit by a tow truck with positive loss of consciousness, GCS of 13 at the scene. She was tachycardic on the scene with bleeding from her right ear and scalp. In the trauma bay the patient was not following commands. She was quickly intubated and a head CT done showed a depressed skull fracture, right occipital bone, traumatic subarachnoid pneumocephalus and right temporal bone fracture. Pelvic films were negative. Chest x-ray showed no pneumothorax. CT of the cervical spine was negative and her cervical spine was eventually cleared.

The patient is a 36 year-old male who presented status post a high speed MVC where he was the unrestrained driver and was ejected from the vehicle approximately thirty feet with positive loss of consciousness. On arrival he was hemodynamically stable through the transfer as well. He presents with an obvious deformity of the right knee. He also presents and complains of left elbow pain and left chest pain.

Patient is a 25 year old male driver of a car who slammed into the back of a truck today, transferred intubated from . His GCS was reportedly less than 7 at the scene of the accident. He was extricated for about 1.5 hours and was apneic and had a heart rate of 50 when EMS arrived, per report. EMS was unable to establish an airway but he was bagged until he arrived to the referring hospital. He was intubated and a chest tube placed (with minimal return). He was hypotensive and received 4 U PRBC there and given 2mg of midazolam for question of seizure activity which involved facial twitching and jaw clenching. The patient was med-flighted to   and had a GCS of 3 upon arrival here.

This is a 40 year old female who was an unrestrained driver, T-boned on the driver's side, ejected from the vehicle with positive loss of consciousness at the scene, found alert and oriented times one, transferred to the outside hospital where was found hemodynamically stable.  coma scale was 15 with crepitus in her left chest. Left chest tube was placed and the patient was intubated for airway protection, hemodynamically stable on transfer.

This patient is a 59-year-old female who is status post restrained passenger in high speed motor vehicle accident. The driver lost control while going 40-50 miles per hour and then side swiped into another car. The car subsequently craned off the road and into the ditch. The patient's head struck the windshield, which then shattered. Positive loss of consciousness. The patient complains of right arm pain, and hand pain, as well as forehead and face pain. X-ray is notable for widen mediastinum, possible widened sacroiliac joint on left, positive right acetabular fracture. Positive open right radius and ulnar fractures.
52M unrestrained driver s/p high-speed rollover motor vehicle crash on .

59 yo female s/p struck by a car at low speed in her employer's driver way. Unclear where she was struck but EMS found the patient on the ground, moving all extremities, and babbling. Once the medication for possible intubation wore off, she was alert and oriented x three but had no memory of the event. She complained of a headache but the remainder of her review of systems was negative.

52 yo man, unrestrained driver, ejected in single car motor vehicle accident. Was seen at an outside hospital and found to have right renal laceration and right ulnar fracture. The patient is a 56 year old male who is an unrestrained driver status post motor vehicle crash versus tree. The patient is a 25-year-old male who paramedics responded to and found him lying in the road. The patient was a helmeted driver of a motor vehicle struck by car which subsequently left the seen. 17 yo unrestrained driver, s/p motor vehicle collision. Prolonged extrication with a GCS 5 at scene; he was subsequently intubated and transported via  to  for ongoing care.

The patient is an 18 year old male involved in a high speed motor vehicle crash/rollover approximately 100 miles per hour who was unrestrained who had a prolonged extrication with significant intrusion into the car. 55 yo male s/p motor vehicle crash, unrestrained driver who felt dizzy and veered off road (per witness). Was taken to an area hospital, CT showed right frontal hemorrhage, he was loaded with Dilantin and then transferred to  for further care ED.

39 y/o female transferred with recent admission s/p being hit by a car (she was pedestrian). She was GCS of 6 at scene with multiple attempts of intubation in route to . When in ED at , intubation was successful. CT of head showed large R SDH, IPH, and frontal skull fracture. CT of c-spine and torso were also done with no abnormal findings. She was transferred to  by ambulance for further neurosurgical workup. She was admitted to neurosurgical service and taken emergently to OR for R craniectomy, with L frontal lobectomy and partial temporal lobectomy and and external ventricular drain placement. Exam improved to withdrawal and some localization to pain, a peg was placed on . Patient had respiratory complications requiring SICU readmission, with possible hosp-associated PNA -> cultures grew out ACINETOBACTER and STENOTROPHOMONAS and abx were tailored to those organisms. The patient was weaned to trach mask. The patient was discharged to rehab.At rehab there was concern for edema over the site of the craniectomy and the patient was sent for a head CT which showed significant hydrocephalus. Per transfer note patient has been afebrile with negative blood cultures She was transferred to  for further eval.

This an 18-year-old male with no significant past medical history, who was the unrestrained driver at an unknown speed of a single car versus tree accident. The patient was intoxicated but had a GCS of 8 initially on the scene. In the Emergency Room, the patient was combative and was intubated for airway protection. He had an obvious right femur deformity and eye lacerations on the right. He was taken to CAT scan which showed multiple punctate hemorrhages in the right and left frontoparietal lobes bilaterally. He was otherwise stable and transferred to the Trauma Service Intensive Care Unit for further management.

The patient is a 79 year old woman who was involved in a high speed motor vehicle crash, unrestrained passenger, car versus wall, with a prolonged extrication time. Was evidently alert at the scene, but became unstable and was intubated in the field. She had multiple facial lacerations, epistaxis and oral bleeding with displaced teeth. Upon presentation to  via Med-Flight transport, she had already been intubated. She was tachycardiac, heart rate 110 to 130, blood pressure 120/palp. She had an open left pretibial wound. She had palpable peripheral pulses. Abdomen was softly distended and nontender. FAST was negative. Rectal was guaiac negative. Chest x-ray was without pneumothorax. Pelvis without fracture. Hematocrit was 34.5. First gas was 7.36, 40, 204, 24, -2. Lactate was 2.6. She had UA with large blood and then she had a DBL which was grossly positive for blood. She was emergently brought to the operating room, also en route receiving three units of packed cells and FFP. Her injuries at this time were noted to be some type of abdominal process causing the bleeding, facial lacerations, open left tib/fib fractures. Head CT showed a small contusion with a small subarachnoid hemorrhage in the left frontal lobe. Incidentally she also had an ex-lap with findings of bleeding from the spleen, two splenic lacerations which were repaired and bleeding stopped with Surgicel. Note was made of a macronodular cirrhosis pattern of her liver. Patient was closed and brought back to the ICU for a very prolonged hospital course. She is Italian speaking only. She was maintained in a hard collar.

Patient is a 24-year-old female transferred to the  from an outside hospital following a motor vehicle accident in which the patient was an unrestrained driver. No loss of consciousness. The patient was noted to have alcohol in her blood.

This is a 61 year-old female with a history of diabetes who was involved in a motor vehicle collision. She was transferred to the  by Life Flight. On initial evaluation, she was hemodynamically stable with a GCS of 15. She had a clearly identifiable right lower extremity injury. The right ankle had a compound fracture with the tibia protruding out over the skin and the whole right foot displaced anteromedially. There was clear avulsion of nearly all of the posterior and medial as well as lateral structures and the foot was tethered to the leg anteriorly by skin and connective tissue bridge. She also had a degloving injury to the right thigh as well as a laceration to the left thigh. She had bilateral Charcot foot and her vascular exam was significant for palpable femoral and popliteal pulses bilaterally. She had pulses to her left foot, however, there was no appreciable pulse on the right foot although the right foot did have capillary refill. Given the degree of the neurovascular injury in combination with the orthopedic injury, it was felt that there would be no meaningful recovery of function for this mangled extremity and the decision was made to amputate the foot after discussion with the patient and her son who agreed with the plan.

On presentatio the patient is an 80 year-old woman found to be in an motor vehicle accident. She is a restrained driver versus a brick wall. She is awake and confused at the scene and became obtunded, intubated by EMS, arrived to  in collar, intubated. GCS of 3. Initial systolic blood pressure of 74, decreased breath sounds on left, left chest tube was placed. Initial attempt went to the abdomen. Repeat systolic blood pressure 110, heart rate 78. Chest x-ray of pelvis. X-ray done, access was obtained, laboratories sent, Foley and G tube placed, to the Operating Room for emergent laparotomy. In the Operating Room difficult to ventilate with decreased systolic blood pressures. Right chest tube was placed with initial return of 200 cc of blood.

54 yo woman, otherwise healthy, unrestrained passenger in 40mph motor vehicle crash with ? LOC (GCS 15 @ scenes per EMS) during which she sustained C2 fracture in addition to multiple orthopedic injuries, rib fractures, pneumothorax and multiple abrasions. She was transported to  for further care.

The patient also had a liver laceration and a splenic laceration. The patient was brought to the Operating Room emergently.

The patient is a 39 year old male who was an unrestrained driver involved in a rollover motor vehicle accident. He was partially ejected from the vehicle. He had a prolonged extrication time, approximately 30 minutes and was found unresponsive by paramedics at the scene and intubated. The patient was transferred to an outside medical facility where he had some left side crepitus noted. He had a left chest tube placed for relief of this pneumothorax. The patient, at that time, was noted to be hypotensive and had a diagnostic peritoneal lavage performed which was negative. The patient's chest x-ray at that time showed a pneumothorax on the opposite side, on the right side, for which another chest tube was placed. The patient was packaged and prepared for transfer through , however, upon wheeling the patient away from that facility, he was found to be hypotensive initially and then had an asystolic arrest. Two additional bilateral chest tubes were placed with relief of bilateral tension hemopneumothoraces with return of perfusing cardiac rhythm.

28 yo male restrained passenger in vehicle that reportedly hydroplaned and hit a tree from the back of the vehicle. This patient is a 81 year old male with a history of atrial fibrillation (on coumadin) and hypertension who was transferred from   with a distal left femur fracture involving his previous total knee replacement. He had a head and C-spine CT which were negative. He had a distal left femur fracture. His INR was 1.7. His systolic blood pressure varied at the OSH, but remained in the 80s prior to transfer. En route, his systolic blood pressure dropped to the 70s. He received 50 of fentanyl and 4 of morphine prior to transfer, and currently complains only of left knee pain. He did not have an abdominal CT scan prior to transfer to .

21F s/p MVC vs tree at approximately 50 MPH, unrestrained. Initially seen at outside hospital, was a&o x3, but became agitated and hypotensive, requiring intubation. 71 yo M with Pt with hx of HTN, HL, OSA, s/p unrestrained MVC rollover on  with TBI, L open ankle fracture, R closed ankle fracture and dislocation, scalp laceration discharged with hospital course complicated prolonged intubation, peri-operative PEA arrest and apnea post-op requiring tracheostomy placement on . He was discharged to rehab on  on trach collar, and was readmitted from  with fever and AMS. His infectious source during the last admission was felt to be related to his deep left leg wound, and he subsequently underwent BKA on  and revision on . He also completed a course of vanco/zosyn during that admission. Per  in , MA , he was initially A&Ox1 when he arrived on . Over the past 2 days prior to admission, he had become more agitated and aggressive. No report of fevers and no diarrhea, they reported that he had no BMs since . He had been receiving Haldol 2mg via G-tube 3-4 times per day and Ativan 0.5mg-1mg for agitation. No report of other new medications started since recent discharge. Per his wife and son-in-law, his mental status has been very variable over the past 2 months. At his best, he is A&Ox1, calm, and recognized his family members although he is disoriented to time and place. They reoprt that he has not been sleeping much, if at all, since arriving to rehab last week.

71 M with history of HTN, HL, OSA, s/p unrestrained MVC rollover on  with TBI, L open ankle fracture, R closed ankle fracture and dislocation, scalp laceration discharged with hospital course complicated prolonged intubation, PEA arrest and apnea post-op requiring tracheostomy placement on . Underwent PEG placement on  for long term nutritional needs. Discharged to rehab on  with external fixator in place on left ankle and open left calcaneal wound s/p debridement on kefzol and trach collar. At rehab, spiked temperature to 102 this morning and ? desaturation to 89%. Sent to  ED for concern of PNA on CXR versus sepsis. . In the ED, patient desated to 84% and improved with bagging and suction. Concern for mucus plugging. Underwent CXR, CTA chest and x-ray of right foot. CTA chest did not show evidence of PNA, PE. Patient required paralyzation with vec for CT scan and subsequently required vent. Started on zosyn/vanc/levofloxacin for concern of wound infection and ? PNA. Because of ventilatory need, patient was admitted to the MICU. Prior to leaving the ED, SBP dropped to 80s and patient was started on levophed 0.18 with good effect and SBPs up to 112. . On arrival to the MICU, patient's VS - T 98.6, HR 85, BP 184/88, RR 14, O2sat 100% on CMV through trach. Patient is sedated, but in NAD .

This is a 72 year oldm man s/p MVC, car vs tree. No history of seizure disorder, 1 episode "posterior head bleed" per family while on Plavix 2 years ago at . He was treated non-operatively and this resolved. He had some peripheral vision loss which has since resolved. No recent illnesses per family.

52 M +EtOH, s/p motorcycle crash intubated on scene w/ left clavicle fracture, left  rib fracture, pulmonary and splenic contusions. He reportedly was not moving left side of body when found by road. 50M unrestrained driver s/p rollover MVC with ejection. Pt was found 10 ft from his car with +LOC. On arrival to the , pt was hypotensive to SBP 50s but mentating appropriately with GCS 15. Exam revealed loss of motor and sensory function below the xiphoid process. Despite fluid resuscitation he remained hypotensive and was started on pressors with suspicion of neurogenic shock. Imaging revealed T3-T5 vertebral body fractures with severe spinal cord injury concerning for transection, along with multiple bony thoracic fractures and a small left hemopneumothorax. He was admitted to the TSICU for close monitoring. Following admission to the TSICU he underwent closure of extensive scalp lacertaions. His respiratory mechanics worsened; found to have progressed to flail chest in the setting of multiple bilateral rib fractures. Given his increasing fatigue, he was intubated, and a left subclavian line was placed. A post-intubation/line film revealed a significantly increased left pneumothorax with increasing pressor requirement. A chest tube was placed which drained approximately 500cc blood upon placement, with hemodynamic improvement thereafter.

52yo male presented to  Hospital s/p motorcycle vs car collision. The pt was traveling at a high rate of speed, swerved and fell. + LOC. He and his motorcycle were found in the middle  of the road. He was wearing a helmet. At , he was alert and oriented x 2. Multiple facial lacerations were noted and a tetanus shot was given. Vitals upon presentation to  were BP 174/101, HR 80, RR 20, 100% on RA. Pelvis, chest, and C-spine  were unremarkable. He was transfered to  for further care. Prior to transfer an ECG had been obtained which showed inferior ST elevations. He was taken to the cath lab. He was intubated using laryngoscopy due to airway swelling. Cath showed thrombotic mid-distal RCA lesion which was stented with BMS x 2. He was then transfered to the CCU. U tox came back + for cocaine. Plastic surgery evaluated and sutured facial lacs. Trauma surgery is folllowing the patient along with CCU team. . Unable to obtain ROS  mental status. . Cardiac review of systems is notable for absence of chest pain, dyspnea on exertion, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, ankle edema, palpitations, syncope or presyncope. . In the ED here, initial vitals were 179/100, HR 84, RR 19, 100% O2 sat.

year old female who is s/p motor vehicle crash as a front passenger on a highway. She was one of three people in the car when the vehicle suffered major damage. 88yo F with HTN admitted for MVC as a restrained passenger was on the floor but had syncope associated with ?bradycardia to mid 30's per report, no tracings available. Initial BP was not obtainable but was reported to be in the 110 s systolic once it was obtainable. Right before the code blue/syncope, she was clammy and cool and may have been given some pain meds and antihypertensives before. Since arriving to the TICU, she has required pressors, initially dopa. But when her HR > 90 s, she would trigger small <1mm ST depression and so she was switched to dopa and norepi. With the dopa, they can get her HR to the 80 s but still need norepi to keep her BP elevated. Without the norepi, her HR would be in the 80 s but hypotensive. Review of floor vital signs shows that her HR was mainly in the 50 with SBP ranging from 100-130.

Of note she recieved narcotics for pain control and all of her antihypertensives prior to the event. She was noted to be clammy/diaphoretic during the event. Mr.  is a 61 year old gentleman who was a restrained driver in a high speed, head on motor vehicle crash. After extrication by report, he was unstable at the scene and he was brought to the  emergency room with hypotension, tachycardia. His initial evaluation demonstrated right flailed chest with crepitus and decreased breath sounds. In the emergency room he had a right chest tube placed after a needle decompression and large bore IV access. He continued to have hypotension in the trauma bay and was given 3000 liters of crystalloid and 2 units of universal blood. A chest x-ray done at that point showed left hemothorax and a left chest tube was placed. Both chest tubes put out about 1000 cc blood before the rate of bleeding slowed down significantly. At this point he again remained hypotensive. A DPL was performed, which was positive for blood and he was emergently brought to the operating room for an exploratory laparotomy.

49 yo male, s/p motorcycle crash vs SUV, helmeted, +LOC and upon awakening was perseverating and disoriented. He was taken to an area hospital and was later transferred to  for continued trauma care. 49yo man with history of cervical injury on Oxycontin as an outpt admitted on  for treatment of a SAH who became agitated and threatening to his nurse when he felt she was not giving him sufficient Oxycontin causing a code purple to be called. The pt was originally admitted to  Hospital after a motorcycle accident, and found to have a SAH on CT and therefore transferred to BIMDC. He was admitted to the SICU on arrival here for close monitoring. While in the ICU pt became agitated, the team attempted to treat this with Haldol and Ativan, but he continued to be agitated. Per the chart a decision was made to selectively intubate the pt on  for safety and in order to be able to get a CT scan. The pt was maintained intubated until  when he was extubated and remained calm and appropriate for transfer. At 8pm tonight pt became agitated because he felt the nurse working with him had given him less pain medications than he should receive. Per the nurse the pt reported to her that he is used to taking Oxycontin 480mg PO a day, and that when he is home he tends to either chew or snort his Oxy's because they give him a buzz that way. The pt also reported to the nurse, per her report, that he chewed the Oxycontin he got here. He reported her that if she would not give him more meds he would call an ambulance to transport him to the . When I arrived pt was saying to the nurse, "All my doctors are at , and I want to go there. There I will get the pain meds I need." He was very angry that security and extra personnel were on the scene, and kept making angry references to the situation. He reported to me that he has a history of neck fracture and has been on Oxycontin for 6 years, he stated, "I am the first to admit that I am a major addict, but that means that just giving me what I get at home when I am having additional pain is not going to work." He felt that the staff at the  do not understand how much pain medication he needs, and that they are not responding to his needs. When the surgical intern, Dr.  , M.D., arrived on the floor the patient explained to him that he needed more pain meds. Dr.  told the pt he would give him more. The patient explained he needed at least three more Oxycontin 80mg pills tonight and more Oxycodone for in between the doses. Dr.  reported to the pt that he would look into how much the pt could get, and add something for breakthrough. Pt became very angry that Dr.  did not know exactly how much pain medication he could get and that he was limited by what the pharmacy would release. He continued to threaten to leave the hospital, but ultimately agreed to stay and take medications overnight. Dr.  suggested to the that he could speak with the am team about the situation, and if he continues unhappy a transfer could be considered. I attempted to complete psych eval, but pt refused further interview because he was in too much pain. He also refused to allow other family members to be contact. After pt got medicated he was willing to briefly review his history, which is detailed below. He denied current SI or HI. He denied current depression, hallucinations of any form or paranoia.

This  admission for this 20-year-old man was occasioned by a motor vehicle accident versus a tree. He was extracted at the site by Emergency Medical Teams with   coma scale of 3 at the scene. He was in the back seat and unrestrained. He was transferred to  after a failed attempt to intubate. He was resuscitated and then flown by EMS crew to  for further care. After successful but difficult intubation, he received six units of packed cells in the  Emergency Unit and stabilized hemodynamically. Chest x-ray showed right pneumothorax and two chest tubes were placed bilaterally. Emergent head CT also revealed diffuse intracranial hemorrhage. The patient is a 17-year-old unrestrained passenger in a motor vehicle crash at questionable speeds. The car did roll over, and there was a question of the patient being pinned underneath the roll bars of the jeep.

The patient is a 41 year-old female status post MVA versus tree, positive airbag deployment, positive ethanol, 25 minute extraction time, question of loss of consciousness.  Coma Scale of 15 on arrival.

The patient was a 54-year-old woman status post motor vehicle roll-over. Patient was a restrained passenger. The vehicle was going approximately 60 miles per hour. No air bag deployed. 22 yo female who s/p MVA on . Restrained driver, skidded on a patch of ice and sideswiped a wall and then hit a telephone pole on her driver's site. -year-old female who was involved in a motor vehicle crash unrestrained backseat passenger vs pole; she was taken to an area hospital and found to have a right supracondylar femur fracture. She was tansferred to  for further care.

40M unknown PMH presents after MVC as unrestrained driver. . Per social work note from ED --- "Per EMS report +LOC, there were no visible skid marks on the road & pt's car went head on into tree. There was concern that crash might have been intentional. However, pt was confused & not arousable in the ED to clarify details. Pt became agitated, threatening & hitting staff, so he was intubated.  Police at the scene reported to EMS that they thought they recognized pt from court earlier in the day. There is a question as to whether pt was the same man from court who had a restraining order taken out against him by brother. This information has not been confirmed. Identification for pt has not been confirmed either. Police took the license in patient's possession. The license listed   DOB , , , MA. Police & EMS could not confirm that it was pt's license. Car was also registered to  ." . In the ED, vitals 60, 110/64, 100% on A/C 550x14/5/100%. On exam, no trauma injuries. GCS 7 or 8 initially. Labs normal, only notable for tox screen positive for benzos. Thought he was clearly intoxicated from something though. Given tetanus shot, haldol, ativan. Intubated for agitation on propofol. CT chest revealed foreign body in esophagus (?coin or battery). GI consulted and thought that most likely a coin based on appearance, plan to get Xray in AM to see if it has cleared and if not then scope at that time. Admit MICU.

60 year old male s/p motorcycle crash at approximately 50 mph, +LOC, one fatality on scene, he was helmeted. Pt found over guard rail w/ open LLE fracture, intubated on scene. Orthopedics was consulted regarding his left open tibia-fibula fracture as well as a left open foot fracture. The peroneal artery appeared to be constricted but patent down to the calcaneus. . This gentleman was hemodynamically unstable in the trauma bay. He was taken emergently to the operating room for stabilization of his tibia fracture.

This gentleman was admitted to  following highspeed motorcycle accident with multiple injuries. male with HTN, hyperlipidemia, prostate Ca, Alzheimer's dementia, admitted  to trauma service s/p MVA. He was a restrained passenger in a vehicle that was involved in a head on collision with another vehicle. The patient was initially hypotensive at the scene but responded to fluid boluses. He was taken to the ED where he c/o CP and was found to be in complete heart block with rate in 20-30s, BP in 40s while getting a CT scan. Transcutaneous pacing was attempted but didn't capture. Given 0.1 mg epi x2 in CT for bradycardia. CT was aborted and pt was intubated. Anesthesiology were called and intravenous pacer was placed through RIJ without complications. The patient responded to pacing with increase in BP to 120/65. Further trauma work up was negative, including head CT and C, T, L spine. He was subsequently cleared by the trauma service and transferred to the CCU service on  pending family's decision regarding PCM placement.

This is a 20 year old gentleman who was an unrestrained driver in a single vehicle motor vehicle accident early in the morning of . Per reports the patient was driving on Route 128 under the influence of ETOH when he swerved off the road into a collection of trees and then back onto the road. There was significant damage to the car with the windshield being blown out and debris surround the patient. He did not require extubation at the scene but was brought to  where he was intubated for airway protection. He had an obvious open right fronto-parietal skull fracture approximately 2cm in size as well as  inches of exposed bone with pieces of what appear to be wood infiltrating the open portion of the fracture. The patient was paralyzed upon arrival of neurosurgery but per reports both at the scene and upon arrival in the ER the patient was moving all extremities and opening his eyes but was not following commands and his GCS was estimated to be 8. He also was noted to have vomited multiple times both in the field and in the ER here. He was pan-scanned per trauma protocol which did not reveal any significant injuries to other parts of his body on preliminary reports and then was taken emergently to the OR for washout and elevation of his open depressed skull fracture.

yo male pedestrian struck by motor vehicle traveling at 30 mph, pt does not recall the event. +windshield spidering. Boarded and collared by EMS. In ED, found to have small SAH, and R rib fractures, small aspiration.

Mr.  is a 43 y.o. male who fell forward over his handlebars while riding his mountain bike. After his fall he experienced +LOC despite having a helmet on. Pt now complains of right hand pain, lower back pain, and left shoulder numbness and weakness.

19 yo F bicyclist struck by a . Per EMS, the  completely ran over her pelvis. She arrived fully A&O to  with anxious affect, able to converse and provide information. Mr.  is a 44 year old man with a history of childhood encephalitis and associated seizures who had a helmeted bike accident on Sunday morning . His accident resulted in   grade 1 AC-joint separation, diastasis of the left frontal zygomatic suture with tiny associated fracture, and loss of consciousness for an unknown period of time. He was in a bicycle road race riding approx 25 mph when he crashed his bike. He was not riding with anyone at the time; he had fallen behind a pack of cyclists and was trying to catch up. He had changed his tires prior to the race and had not broken them in. The last thing he remembers is going down a . He speculates that he might have seen something that caused him to slam on his brakes. His girlfriend reports that the damage to the bike only includes bent handlebars and a damaged left pedal with no serious damage to the wheels or frame. EMS found him with decreased responsiveness and took him to  shortly after the accident. Upon arrival his pupils were equal and reactive. He was oriented to name and place but not date. He was not initially agitated, but became acutely agitated in the CT scanner, became physically aggressive, and was unable to be verbally or physicially restrained. Ativan 2 mg IV was given without success. He was intubated and sedated with etomidate and succinylcholine to obtain CT scans and x-rays. He was transferred here on Monday morning  for further evaluation for his "confusion and head injury."

The patient is a 40 year old male who was riding a bicycle with no helmet and had been drinking alcohol. He fell and was unconscious for about 5 minutes. He went to an OSH where a CT scan showed facial fractures and a questionable IPH.

63 M who was transferred to  after falling from him bike. CT scans from the outside hospital showed a R. SAH and small SDH. He also suffered a L. clavicle fracture and several right sided rib fratcures.

53 yo M who presents s/p flipping over bike handlebars during triathlon today. He was wearing helmet, struck the left side of his head during fall. Mr.  is a 40-year-old Caucasian male who was the fortunate victim of a motor vehicle versus bicyclist collision approximately 2 weeks prior to this surgical procedure. The patient had remained intubated in an intensive care unit environment for the majority of his prior hospitalization and a decision for definitive facial reconstruction surgery was deferred until this admision.

57 yo female with fall from bike. + LOC 5 min. Wearing helmet. c/o back pain, bilateral hand numbness/tingling.

59F helmeted rider of a bicycle vs auto.

85M s/p ped vs. auto, dragged about 20 feet, sustaining multiple injuries on . The patient does not recall the event but he does know where he is now. complains of pain in his head and neck. feels subjectively weaker in L leg.

48 M s/p pedestrian vs. auto on , high speed and thrown 10 feet, + loss of consciousness, brought in to ER hemodynamically unstable, with SBP's in the 70's, pelvic instability noted and his pelvis was wrapped in a sheet, left lower extremity was splinted. The patient was given antibiotics, Kefzol, leg splints, because a CT was noted to have a tibia/fibula fracture at the right lower extremity.

49 w/ h/o IVDU, HCV who is s/p high speed MVC rollover. She was found in the passenger seat, no LOC but was lethargic on arrival to an OSH. She was given narcan with neurological reponse and had a GCS of 9T. She had a degloving injury of the L hand.

Mr.  is an 84 year-old male with a past medical history of atrial fibrillation, coronary disease, history of congestive heart failure unknown EF, prior pacemaker insertion, history of hypertension, hypercholesterolemia and gastroesophageal reflux disease who was a restrained driver in a motor vehicle accident versus pole and found to be in GCS of 14 or 15 somewhat confused on the scene complaining of some mild abdominal pain. The patient was relatively hypotensive in the field, however, was fluid resuscitated and stabilized on transfer. He did have a positive seat belt sign noted in the field. There was no report of loss of consciousness, however, it was unclear if he did in fact have loss of consciousness. In the trauma bay the patient was somewhat hypotensive. He additionally was mildly tachycardic in the low 100s. His ETLS survey revealed negative fast examination with somewhat tender abdomen, stable pelvis examination. His chest was unremarkable with clear breath sounds bilaterally. He was a GCS 14 upon arrival and was somewhat confused in speech. Thereafter he was sent to the scanner where a CT of the head showed no evidence of intracranial bleed or injury, no skull fracture. CT of the C spine was negative for any bony injury or malalignment. CT of the chest showed no evidence of great vessel injury, mediastinal injury or pulmonary contusion. No evidence of pneumothorax or rib fracture. CT of the abdomen did reveal evidence of free fluid likely positive for hemoperitoneum. Because of his relative tachycardia and a positive CT of the abdomen showing likely hemoperitoneum a diagnostic peritoneal lavage was performed showing positive blood. Therefore the patient was taken to the Operating Room for exploration.

43M s/p MVC car vs. tree. +EtOH, unknown LOC, +marijuana and cocaine. Pt was reportedly hypotensive (SBP 90) and tachycardic in the field. PT was brought to  ED and found to have a GCS of 15. Pt became acutely bradycardic with heart rate down to the 30's and was intubated. Pt was then taken to MRI for C-spine MRI and neck MRA.

60 yo female s/p rollover motor vehicle collision; ?LOC She was taken to an area hospital and was transferred to  for further care. Initially she was hemodynamically stable with normal pulse and pressure. However, she developed hemodynamic instability and apparent blood loss anemia. A left sided thoracostomy tube was placed for a hemothorax. Attempt at DPL revealed no return of fluid on aspiration and the guidewire and catheter could not be advanced. CT scan of her abdomen confirmed splenic injury. She was emergently taken to the operating room by Dr. .

23yo F presents to  by med-flight s/p MVC on . Pt found at scene moving all extremities but not following commands. Intubated for altered mental status, not following commands & combative. Obvious bilateral lower leg fractures with deformity.

The patient is a 21-year-old, unrestrained driver in a motor vehicle accident car versus pole with intrusion. The patient was unresponsive at the scene and taken to an outside hospital where he was intubated and sedated. The CT scan from the outside hospital shows a left subdural hematoma, basal skull fracture, a left temporal contusion, right subarachnoid hemorrhage and multiple facial fractures. Chest, abdomen and pelvis films were negative. His chest x-ray showed left lower lobe atelectasis. He had no solid organ injuries and no vascular injuries. He was admitted to the trauma Intensive Care Unit and had a ventriculostomy drain placed. He had a repeat CAT scan on post hospital day number one that showed no interval change. He was monitored and given Mannitol 50 q.6h. intravenously for increased intracranial pressure. Facial fractures include left linear zygomatic fracture, bilateral nasal fracture, bilateral xiphoid fracture, right supraorbital commuted fracture, left temporal lobe contusion with fracture of the basal skull in that area. The patient remained in critical condition. Neurology was consulted for a possible question of seizure activity. EEG was done, and Neurology felt that his tremors the patient was having was likely either related to alcohol and drug withdrawal or coming off sedation medication and not seizure activity. On , the patient had a repeat head CT that showed increased mass effect and edema. He was continued on Mannitol 50 intravenously every six hours, and a second ventriculostomy drain was placed at that time due to increased edema.

35 yo F restrained driver, high speed, hit guardrail. +LOC GCS 14 on scene. Seen at OSH - found to have scalp lac, CT Head negative, CT abd/pelvis w/ L2 transverse process fx, pelvic fxs, pelvic hematoma w/ contrast extravasation. Transferred to . On arrival hemodynamically stable, c/o left hip, llq pain.

The patient is a 27-year-old female who was an unrestrained passenger in a car versus tree motor vehicle accident. She was thrown approximately 60 feet. Her  coma score was 15 initially. She was found to be tachycardic with systolic blood pressures in the 90's, which was responsive to fluid.

58 yo M med-flighted to  from  following an unhelmuted, over the handlebar, motorcycle accident. Pt reportedly intoxicated, but was awake and alert at the accident scene, talking with paramedics, but became increasingly combative, and then less responsive and was intubated prior to transfer.

This 86-year-old female was struck by an SUV with significant damage to the SUV's front end on . The patient had a loss of consciousness after this collision and was taken to an outside hospital where her systolic blood pressure was in the 60s. She was intubated and transfused. She was subsequently transferred to  where she was hemodynamically unstable in the trauma bay. She received 6 units of packed red blood cells and 5 liters of crystalloid. Status post this treatment her blood pressure improved to about the 120s systolic. The patient was taken to the CT scan for scanning of her head, neck, chest and belly but this scan was aborted once her systolic blood pressures again fell to the 70s. She was then taken to the intensive care unit where bedside echocardiogram was performed and was negative for tamponade. A DPL was also performed which was negative. A chest x-ray showed widened mediastinum and this was followed up by the patient being taken to the angiography suite where no bleeding from the aortic arch or pelvic vessels was demonstrated. As the patient was hemodynamically stable she was taken back to the intensive care unit where a repeat echocardiogram was performed. This study was consistent with significant pericardial fluid.
21 yo female who was the restrained passenger in MVC. Transferred to  as a trauma patient.

The patient is a 19-year-old woman unrestrained driver struck on the passenger side of her vehicle who required jaws of life extrication from the vehicle and intubation in the field. Chest CT shows evidence of a hemopneumothorax. Head CT shows evidence of subarachnoid hemorrhage, subdural hematoma and intraparenchymal hemorrhage.

The patient is a 16 year old male who was the restrained driver in a high speed motor vehicle collision, car versus tree with death of the passenger at the scene. At the scene patient's GCS was 5 and he was combative. He was intubated at the scene. There was witnessed aspiration at the scene and gastric contents were suctioned from the ET tube. No hypotension throughout the rescue at the scene and no hypertension during transfer. Patient did have O2 desaturation to 86% after the aspiration which improved with suctioning. Patient was transferred to  for management.

This is a 47 year-old woman with no significant past medical history who was med flighted to  on day of admission after an motor vehicle accident in  . She was the only person in the vehicle and was found to have collided with a tree. She was an unrestrained driver and the air bag was deployed. At the scene she was combative not following commands, though moving all extremities and so was intubated for airway protection. On arrival to  CT of head, C spine, chest, abdomen and pelvis were all unremarkable and trauma plain films showed fracture only at the right distal fibula, which was splinted. She did well since arrival and was about to be extubated on the day of admission, but when the Propofol was decreased she again became agitated and was not following commands. The Propofol was then increased and she remained intubated overnight.

Mr  is a 26 year old right-handed man who was recently hospitalized at  from  through  for multiple injuries sustained after a motor vehicle accident. For the details please refer to previous discharge summary. In summary, on , the patient sustained an unrestrained 28 feet ejection. He sustained a severe head injury with a reported  Coma Scale of 14 at the scene. The patient developed a retrograde amnesia of the events preeceding the accident of about one hour and post traumatic amnesia for about two months. He also developed traumatic aortic dissection, liver laceration, severe pulmonary contusion. He was intubated for two and a half months due to recurrent pneumonias. Other Injuries included bilateral orbital fractures, pelvic fracture, left radial fracture, pneumo and hemothorax. After a prolonged hospital stay, the patient underwent rehabilitation at  Hospital. On  while at  Hospital, he had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. At that time, it was decided to transfer him to  for further management. He had a second seizure en- route and a third in     Emergency Room. In the  ER he was treated with a total of 8 mg of Ativan, 1 gm of Dilantin. His magnesioum level was 1.1 mg/dl. He was intubated in the Emergency Room and treated with 20 mg/kg/dose of Phenobarbital. His head CT was normal. A CSF sample obtained by lumbar puncture showed three white blood cells, 1500 red blood cells. A second tube was clear and colorless. Blood cultures from  showed coagulase negative Staphylococcus as well as coagulase negative Staphylococcus which was resistant to Cephalin. He was extubated on  and tranferred to the Neurology Service for further management.
Mr.  was involved in a high speed MVA where he sustained a T11 burst fracture. He had no left leg movement in the EW and sensation was patchy throughout both lower extremities.

This is a 50-year-old male with unknown past medical history other than bilateral inguinal hernia repairs that was admitted to the trauma service after suffering a motor vehicle collision as the driver. Patient is a 32-year-old man involved in a motor vehicle accident as an unrestrained driver and/or passenger in a rollover. Patient was intubated in the Trauma Bay to facilitate reduction of his left posterior lateral hip dislocation which was done without incident. Patient's trauma work-up revealed injuries including a large midline chin laceration with a lingual communication, a left acetabular fracture, right medial malleolus fracture and a talotibial separation. CT scan also revealed a small pelvic hematoma without extravasation. Patient was noted to have ethanol and cocaine onboard at the time of the accident. Following these studies, the patient was transferred to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit where he remained intubated overnight and was extubated the next morning without incident. He was transferred to the floor where he was seen by the Addiction Consultation Service and where he underwent aggressive Physical Therapy.

51 y/  with closed head injury s/p MVC. On arrival to trauma bay pt with GCS of  with waxing and  of mental status. Pt electively intubated. No other obvious injuries noted on primary survey. Pt taken for emergent head, C-spine, chest/abd/pelvis CT.

This is a 71-year-old female who was in a motor vehicle accident, car vs tree. She was unrestrained driver. She had positive loss of consciousness at the scene. She was complaining of left arm pain, sternal and left upper quadrant pain. She was transferred to an outside hospital where her blood pressure was found to be 80/30 and was noted to have increasing abdominal pain with distention. She had a CT scan that showed a splenic laceration with free fluid around the liver and spleen. Her head CT demonstrated multiple facial fractures. She had a left proximal humerus fracture and distal radial fracture. She has a history of aortic valve replacement, mechanical valve on Coumadin with an initial INR of 3.9 and hematocrit of 29. At this point she was Med Flighted to the  for further treatment. She had received two units of packed red blood cells, 2 liters of intravenous fluids, Vitamin K, FFP on transfer. She had a fast exam that was positive for free fluid.

54 yo M with a PMH significant for tardive dyskinesia (? secondary to prolonged Clozapine exposure), bipolar disorder, multiple abdominal surgeries (Roux-en-Y gastric bybass, distal pancreatectomy, splenectomy, revision of gastrectomy/choledochojejunostomy), Vit D/Vit B12/testosterone deficiency, and anemia of chronic disease who presents as unrestrained driver in MVC. 48-year-old male status post motor vehicle accident this morning, who presents as a transfer from . Briefly, this was an unrestrained driver, driving at 60 miles an hour, who suffered a significant car accident. Subsequently he complained of severe chest pain and was neurologically intact at that time. Electrocardiogram revealed ST segment elevations and left anterior fascicular block. The patient was intubated at this time, and transferred to , where he developed ventricular tachycardia and was given 300 mg of amiodarone with successful cardioversion. Chest x-ray revealed a widened mediastinum with a CT scan showing no aneurysm or dissection. The patient sustained a left eye laceration and CT of the head showed intrapeduncular subarachnoid hemorrhage. Cardiac catheterization revealed a total occlusion of the proximal left anterior descending which was dilated and stented, however, there was severe no reflow. The rest of the coronary arteries were without disease. The patient was put on an intra-aortic balloon pump for afterload reduction and hemodynamic augmentation. At this time, he was transferred to the Coronary Care Unit for post-catheterization management.

A 25-year-old male status post motor vehicle accident in . Injuries sustained included an intracranial hemorrhage, subarachnoid hemorrhage, left temporal contusion, C2 ring fracture, as well as splenic and hepatic lacerations, pneumothorax. The patient was admitted on the 5th for a cervical fusion.

Enterococcus in the first one at beginning of  for which she is currently being treated with augmentin. . Family reports patient is responding to questions and moving all four extremities. Agitated today but unable to speak. Husband figured out she needed to use the bathroom using yes or no questions.

Mr.   is a 29-year-old gentleman who was involved in a motor vehicle accident. He was a passenger in the back seat, resulting in a motor vehicle collision. He sustained the isolated injury to his acetabulum as described. The patient was initially managed with traction while temporizing him for surgery and stabilizing him from this standpoint. He is now ready for surgery and proceeding to the operating room for repair of his acetabular fracture. The plan is to perform modified extensive approach as described by  and . In order to address both the significant posterior wall comminution, posterior wall and anterior column and posterior column transverse nature of the fracture, the posterior wall has a very high piece involving the weightbearing bone which I think will not be possible to reduce via a posterior approach.

35 yo male s/p motorcycle crash who was transferred from another hospital. He was driving a motorcycle on the way to work and slid to avoid hitting a squirrel. There was no loss of consciousness. 43M s/p unhelmeted motorcycle crash this afternoon was taken to outside hospital and found to have a pneumothorax and comminuted right acetabular fracture with a pelvic hematoma. Mr.  is a 47 yo Right handed man with no significant past medical history. At 3pm today he was riding his motorcycle out of his driveway. Per report of his friend  (who was going to go riding with him) his bike started to tilt to one side, at which point he tried to right it and the bike seemingly flipped over. This occurred before he was able to get to the end of his driveway (suggesting that he could not have been going that fast). The patient's friend states that Mr.  struck his head upon falling off the bike. He was helmeted, but upon impact the helmet flew off. The bike then rolled over him and he eventually landed about 20 feet away from his initial fall with the bike on top of him. His friend rushed to him to find him unconscious. 911 was called and the patient seemingly remained unsconscious for a period of  minutes (other notes put this at less than 5 minutes). He then began to wake up but was agitated and combative. His sensorium began to clear when he arrived at an OSH, but he continued to be perseverative and "confused." He had a head CT showing Left parietal SAH, R parietal skull fx, R anterior temporal SDH and was subsequently medflighted to .
